    Any permit, whether for fishing or keeping a boat in the lake, may be revoked and taken up whenever the holder thereof willfully violates any of the rules and regulations governing fishing or boating in the lake or any of the restrictions attached to such permit or has been guilty of conduct tending to impair the purity or sanitary condition of the water in the lake. 
(Code 1964, § 11-13; Code 1982, § 13-47) 
Sec. 38-91. - Boat equipment and numbering. 
    All boats, whether privately- or city-owned, shall be equipped with at least one approved life preserver for each person, and each boat shall be equipped with a pail to be used for sanitary purposes. Each boat shall be numbered for identification with numerals not less than three inches high and the register shall show the number of the boat used. City-owned boats shall use numbers ten to 99 and privately owned boats from 100 and up. Official boats will use numbers one to nine. 
(Code 1964, § 11-8; Code 1982, § 13-48) 
Sec. 38-92. - Responsibility for wearing life preservers. 
    It shall be the responsibility of the adult operator of a boat on the lake to make certain that all persons in such boat who cannot swim shall wear a life preserver at all times during which they occupy the boat. 
(Code 1964, § 11-24; Code 1982, § 13-49) 
Sec. 38-93. - Limitations on horsepower and load of boats. 
(a)  All boats launched on Lake Michie will be restricted to comply with safe passenger load and an appropriate horsepower capacity; both of which will be determined by the size of the boat. 
(b)  The lake warden shall enforce the safe load restrictions and horsepower capacity standards developed by the United States Coast Guard and the Boating Industry Association for this purpose. These standards shall be posted in public view at the boathouse. 
(Code 1964, § 11-21; Code 1982, § 13-50) 
Sec. 38-94. - Ages of persons in boats. 
    All persons in boats under 16 years of age must be accompanied by an adult. The number of children under age 12 in any boat may not exceed three, and in no case shall there be more than two children under 12 years per adult person in any boat. 
(Code 1964, § 11-23; Code 1982, §§ 13-51, 13-63; Ord. No. 13574, Pt. 1, 4-7-2008) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 13574, Pt. 1, adopted April 7, 2008, changed the title of § 38-94 from "Limitation on number of children in boats" to "Ages of persons in boats." 
Sec. 38-95. - Where boats may land. 
    No shore landings by boat shall be made at other than the designated boat landing. 
(Code 1964, § 11-15; Code 1982, § 13-52) 
Sec. 38-96. - Securing and anchoring of privately owned boats. 
    Every privately owned boat shall be properly secured near the boat dock of the lake and shall be anchored at the owner's expense and responsibility. 
(Code 1964, § 11-9; Code 1982, § 13-53) 
Sec. 38-97. - When fishing and boating permitted. 
    Fishing and boating will be permitted between sunrise and sunset only, at which time the warden's office shall remain open. 
(Code 1964, § 11-12; Code 1982, § 13-54) 
Sec. 38-98. - Reports at beginning and conclusion of use of boats. 
    The person in charge of any boat used on the lake for boating or fishing, shall report prior to and at the conclusion of such use to the lake warden at the dock designated by the city council for such purpose. 
(Code 1964, § 11-20; Code 1982, § 13-55) 
Sec. 38-99. - Causing hazardous wake prohibited. 
    No boats on Lake Michie shall be operated at such rate of speed or in any manner so as to cause or create a wake of such size or intensity as to be hazardous. The lake warden may cause the removal of any boat violating the provisions of this section, and may refuse the privilege of future use of the lake of such boat or of any boat by such person. 
(Code 1964, § 11-30; Code 1982, § 13-56) 
Sec. 38-100. - Water skiing prohibited. 
    Water skiing on the lake is hereby prohibited. 
(Code 1964, § 11-22; Code 1982, § 13-57) 
Sec. 38-101. - Inspection, etc., of fish. 
    The lake warden may inspect any catch of any person fishing at the lake and make a record of the number caught and the approximate net combined weight. Any fish not equal to the regulation sizes or in excess of the number limit shall be confiscated. 
(Code 1964, § 11-14; Code 1982, § 13-58) 
Sec. 38-102. - Bank fishing. 
    The regulations applicable to bank fishing shall be as follows: 
(1)  Bank fishing shall be under the jurisdiction and supervision of the lake warden and assistant wardens at all times and shall be subject to all rules and regulations passed by the city council, the state board of health and the state wildlife resources commission. 
(2)  All persons shall use only those refuse receptacles and sanitary facilities provided by the city. 
(3)  All persons shall enter and leave the designated bank fishing area only by the entrance provided. 
(4)  No person shall fish except in the area designated for that purpose. 
(5)  No person less than 12 years of age may fish unless accompanied by an adult. 
(Code 1964, § 11-16; Code 1982, § 13-59) 
Sec. 38-103. - Fishing near dock. 
    No fishing will be permitted within a radius of 50 feet from the dock of the fishing station of Lake Michie. 
(Code 1964, § 11-17; Code 1982, § 13-60) 
Sec. 38-104. - Areas for picnicking, camping, etc. 
    Picnicking and cleaning or cooking of fish or other foods on the shore of the municipal reservoir is prohibited, except in the picnic area designated for this purpose. Camping, archery and other recreation, other than water recreation, shall take place only in those areas designated for such purposes. 
(Code 1964, § 11-25; Code 1982, § 13-61) 
Sec. 38-105. - Supervision of archery. 
    All archery will be supervised by members of the recreation department or an agent thereof. 
(Code 1964, § 11-26; Code 1982, § 13-62) 
Sec. 38-106. - Firearms and fireworks. 
(a)  No unauthorized person shall fire a gun or pistol or any firecracker or other fireworks from a boat on the lake or from the shore. 
(b)  No person shall be given a permit who shall have in his or her possession on Lake Michie or the property thereof any firearm or firecracker of any kind, except as provided in section 38-114. 
(c)  No unauthorized person shall have firearms or fireworks on city-owned land. 
(d)  The provisions of subsections (b) and (c) of this section shall not apply to the lawful carrying of a concealed handgun by a person pursuant to a permit issued under G.S. 14-415.10 et seq. 
(e)  For violation of this section, the maximum fine shall be $500.00, and the maximum term of imprisonment shall be 30 days. 
(Code 1964, § 11-28; Code 1982, § 13-64; Ord. No. 9738, § 1, 12-21-1992; Ord. No. 10626, § 6, 11-6-1995) 
Sec. 38-107. - Pollution of water. 
(a)  No person shall spit, bathe, swim or put his or her feet in the reservoir or commit any act that will affect the purity of the water. 
(b)  Any person polluting the waters of Lake Michie in any manner will be prosecuted and such pollution shall be sufficient cause for refusing such person permission to fish or use any city-owned property or facility. 
(Code 1964, § 11-29; Code 1982, § 13-65) 
Sec. 38-108. - Parking areas. 
    Parking shall be permitted only in designated parking areas. 
(Code 1964, § 11-31; Code 1982, § 13-66) 
Sec. 38-109. - Alcoholic beverages-Use. 
    Except as provided in section 38-21, the use of any alcoholic beverage is prohibited. 
(Code 1964, § 11-32; Code 1982, § 13-67) 
Sec. 38-110. - Same-Persons showing evidence of intoxication. 
    Persons showing evidence of intoxication shall not be permitted to enter a boat or go upon Lake Michie. Persons discovered on the lake in such condition shall have their permits taken up and shall be conducted back to the dock by the lake warden. 
(Code 1964, § 11-40; Code 1982, § 13-68) 
Sec. 38-111. - Where fires may be built; leaving fires unattended. 
    Fires shall be built only in designated approved ovens. Fires shall never be left unattended. 
(Code 1964, § 11-34; Code 1982, § 13-69) 
Sec. 38-112. - Cutting trees, etc. 
    The cutting of trees, bushes, shrubs and wildflowers is prohibited. 
(Code 1964, § 11-36; Code 1982, § 13-70) 
Sec. 38-113. - Killing wildlife. 
    Killing and taking or in any way molesting wildlife is prohibited. 
(Code 1964, § 11-37; Code 1982, § 13-71) 
Sec. 38-114. - Duck hunting on Lake Michie. 
    Notwithstanding the provisions of any other section of this Code or any other ordinance, duck hunting on Lake Michie in accordance with permits issued by the director of the department of recreation, or the director's designee, is lawful and is allowed. 
(Code 1964, § 11-37.1; Code 1982, § 13-71.1; Ord. No. 5021, § 1, 11-6-1978) 
Sec. 38-115. - Tail race at Flat River pumping station and plant-Use prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to fish, trespass, play, or loiter in or on any portion of the tail race at the Flat River pumping station and plant at Lake Michie. 
(Code 1964, § 11-44; Code 1982, § 13-72) 
Sec. 38-116. - Same-Posting. 
    The city manager shall have a sufficient number of copies of section 38-115 posted on and about the tail race at the Flat River pumping station and plant at Lake Michie in print of such size and arrangement as will be likely to bring notice of the existence of such section to any persons who may come on or about the premises; and shall cause to be posted such additional signs and notices to the public as may be necessary or advisable to acquaint persons coming on the premises of the existence of such section. 
(Code 1964, § 11-45; Code 1982, § 13-73) 
Secs. 38-117-38-147. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - LITTLE RIVER LAKE AREA 

Sec. 38-148. - Purpose and scope. 
    In order to adequately protect the quality of water in the Little River Lake and for other purposes including the protection of city property, this article is adopted. Nothing in this article shall be construed to violate the regulations of the North Carolina Commission for Health Services, and the North Carolina Wildlife Resources Commission. 
(Code 1982, § 13-80; Ord. No. 7532, § 1, 6-20-1988) 
Sec. 38-149. - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this article, the following terms shall have the indicated meanings: 
    Authorized personnel shall be any law enforcement officer or the manager. 
    Little River Lake shall be the "Class I Public Water Supply Reservoir" (as defined by the Rules Governing Public Water Supplies of Title 10, Chapter 10, Subchapter 10D of the North Carolina Administrative Code) owned by the city and located on the Little River. 
    Little River Lake Area shall be Little River Lake and the Little River Land. 
    Little River Land shall be the city-owned land contiguous to Little River Lake. 
    Recreational use and recreational activities include but are not limited to fishing, boating, and picnicking. 
    Under the influence of an impairing substance and operator shall have the same meanings as set forth in G.S. 20-4.01. 
(Code 1982, § 13-81; Ord. No. 7532, § 1, 6-20-1988) 
Sec. 38-150. - Posting. 
    Copies of this article and rules and regulations applying to use of the Little River Lake Area shall be posted conspicuously on Little River Land. 
(Code 1982, § 13-82; Ord. No. 7532, § 1, 6-20-1988) 
Sec. 38-151. - Ejection. 
    Any authorized personnel may cause the ejection and removal from the Little River Lake Area of any person violating this article or any other law, regulation, or rule applicable to the Little River Lake Area. If any passenger in, or the permittee for, a boat on Little River Lake intentionally or negligently violates this article or any of the rules and regulations governing recreational use of the Little River Lake Area or any of the restrictions attached to the permit for the use of said boat or commits conduct tending to impair the purity or sanitary condition of Little River Lake, then the permit to operate said boat shall be surrendered forthwith to the authorized personnel (without refund of any rentals), and said passenger and the permittee for said boat shall be required to promptly leave the Little River Lake Area and not return the same day. If any person not a passenger in a boat intentionally or negligently violates this article or any of the rules and regulations governing recreational use of the Little River Lake Area or commits conduct tending to impair the purity or sanitary condition of Little River Lake, then said person shall be required to promptly leave the Little River Lake Area and not return the same day. 
(Code 1982, § 13-4; Ord. No. 7532, § 1, 6-20-1988) 
Sec. 38-152. - Pollution. 
    No person may spit, bathe, swim, put any part of the body in, or place any substance (except as authorized or allowed by this article) in Little River Lake or commit any other act that is likely to adversely affect the purity of the water; nor shall any person urinate or defecate at the Little River Lake Area except in designated facilities. 
(Code 1982, § 13-85; Ord. No. 7532, § 1, 6-20-1988) 
Sec. 38-153. - Permit. 
    No person may fish in (whether from the bank or from a boat) or boat on Little River Lake except as allowed by the terms of the permit issued to such person by authorized personnel. The city council may set fees for the issuance of permits and for the rental of city-owned equipment. The following provisions apply to Little River Lake Area: 
(1)  Fishing. 
a.  Bank fishing activities shall be under the supervision of authorized personnel at all times. 
b.  No person shall bank or pier fish except in the areas designated for that purpose. No fishing may be conducted from any boat not rented from the city. 
c.  No person may enter or leave the designated bank fishing area except by the entrances and exits designated. 
d.  No person younger than 12 years of age may fish unless accompanied by an adult. 
(2)  Boating. 
a.  Except for emergency, security and maintenance purposes by authorized personnel, as provided by subsection (2)j. of this section, or as directed by authorized personnel, the only means of transportation allowed on Little River Lake are city-owned boats. 
b.  Any use of any boat motor other than city-owned electric motors is prohibited with the exception that other types of boat motors may be used by authorized personnel, as provided by subsection (2)j. of this section, or as directed by authorized personnel, for emergency, security, and maintenance purposes. 
c.  The permittee for boating shall make certain that all persons who cannot swim shall wear a life preserver at all times during which they occupy the boat for which the permit was issued. 
d.  All shore landings shall be made only at the designated boat landing areas. 
e.  No more than two children under 12 years per one adult person may be in any boat. 
f.  Except for authorized personnel, as provided by subsection (2)j. of this section, boating is prohibited within a radius of 1,000 yards of the intakes and dam of Little River Lake. 
g.  After use of a city-owned boat, the permittee shall return it and all other city-owned equipment to the designated area and report to authorized personnel. 
h.  No person shall enter, be the operator of, or be a passenger in any boat while under the influence of an impairing substance. No permit may be issued to any person who is under the influence of an impairing substance. Persons in a boat who are under the influence of an impairing substance shall have their permits revoked and shall be conducted back to the dock by the authorized personnel. 
i.  The permittee for a boat shall take such action as is needed to prevent passengers from committing any violations of this article or other conduct for which a person may be ejected from the Little River Lake Area. 
j.  Nonmotorized boats whose operators have first received a permit may enter the Little River Lake from Little River. The permit shall allow those boats to be on the lake only while crossing the lake for the purpose of reaching the takeout point designated by the city manager on the west side of Highway 501. The boats must proceed without delay to the takeout point and be removed without delay at the takeout point from the Little River Lake Area. 
(Code 1982, § 13-86; Ord. No. 7532, § 1, 6-20-1988; Ord. No. 10190, §§ 1-5, 6-20-1994) 
Sec. 38-154. - Locations for activities and individuals. 
    All recreational activities on the Little River Lake Area are prohibited except in the places designated for that purpose. Except as otherwise provided in this article, the manager may designate certain areas as usable for specific recreational uses. No person other than authorized personnel may be on any part of the Little River Lake Area except in the places designated for recreational use. The dam area, including the intake area, spillway area, and pump station area, at Little River Lake shall not be a recreation area. The manager shall cause the premises to be posted, in a manner reasonably likely to come to the attention of the public, with notice not to enter the premises closed to persons who are not authorized personnel. 
(Code 1982, § 13-87; Ord. No. 7532, § 1, 6-20-1988) 
Sec. 38-155. - Time limits for activities. 
    All recreational activities in the Little River Lake Area shall take place only during the times designated by the director of the department of parks and recreation or the director's designee. 
(Code 1982, § 13-88; Ord. No. 7532, § 1, 6-20-1988) 
Sec. 38-156. - Alcoholic beverages. 
    The consumption of any alcoholic beverage in the Little River Lake Area is prohibited. 
(Code 1982, § 13-89; Ord. No. 7532, § 1, 6-20-1988) 
Sec. 38-157. - Firearms. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to possess a firearm, air rifle, air pistol, pump gun, or other similar weapon of any kind in or upon the Little River Lake Area. This section shall not apply to sworn law enforcement officers, and the lawful carrying of a concealed handgun by a person pursuant to a permit issued under G.S. 14-415.10 et seq. 
(b)  For violation of this section, the maximum fine shall be $500.00, and the maximum term of imprisonment shall be 30 days. 
(Code 1982, § 13-90; Ord. No. 7532, § 1, 6-20-1988; Ord. No. 9738, § 1, 12-21-1992; Ord. No. 10626, § 7, 11-6-1995) 
Sec. 38-158. - Parking. 
    Parking is prohibited on Little River Land except in designated parking areas. 
(Code 1982, § 13-91; Ord. No. 7532, § 1, 6-20-1988) 
Sec. 38-159. - Fires. 
    Fires in the Little River Lake Area shall be allowed only in designated-approved grills. Fires shall never be left unattended. 
(Code 1982, § 13-92; Ord. No. 7532, § 1, 6-20-1988) 
Sec. 38-160. - Digging; flora. 
    The cutting, tearing, pulling, or otherwise causing damage to trees, bushes, shrubs and wildflowers, and the digging into or scraping of the ground in the Little River Lake Area are prohibited, except by or under the direction of authorized personnel. 
(Code 1982, § 13-93; Ord. No. 7532, § 1, 6-20-1988) 
Sec. 38-161. - Wildlife. 
    Except as otherwise provided by this article, killing, taking, or in any way molesting wildlife in the Little River Lake Area is prohibited. 
(Code 1982, § 13-94; Ord. No. 7532, § 1, 6-20-1988) 
Sec. 38-162. - Cleaning of fish. 
    Cleaning of fish in the Little River Lake Area is prohibited. 
(Code 1982, § 13-95; Ord. No. 7532, § 1, 6-20-1988) 
Sec. 38-163. - Metal detectors. 
    The use of a metal detector on the Little River Lake Area is prohibited, except by or under the direction of authorized personnel. 
(Code 1982, § 13-96; Ord. No. 7532, § 1, 6-20-1988) 
Chapter 42 - PERSONNEL 

Sec. 42-1. - Purpose of chapter. 
    It is the purpose of this chapter to establish a fair and uniform system of personnel administration for all employees of the city under the supervision of the city manager. 
(Code 1964, § 2-17; Code 1982, § 14-1) 
Sec. 42-2. - Rules and regulations. 
    The city manager shall establish and make available to employees such detailed rules and regulations, not inconsistent with this chapter as are necessary to implement and promote good personnel administration. The city manager shall be responsible for all phases of personnel administration not specifically reserved for the council and shall perform all duties essential to effective personnel administration. The manager shall comply with all applicable federal, state and local laws with regard to personnel policy development and implementation. 
    The manager shall administer all city personnel programs, such as classification and compensation plans, retirement systems in accordance with the Local Government Employees' Retirement System, testing and training programs, and grievance and appeal procedures, and shall establish such personnel rules, plans and procedures necessary or desirable to implement the provisions of this chapter. 
(Code 1964, § 2-26.2; Code 1982, § 14-2; Ord. No. 13408, § 1, 8-7-2006) 
Sec. 42-3. - Municipal employment. 
    Appointments to positions and subsequent employment with the city shall be on the basis of merit, fitness and general suitability of the individual and shall be in accordance with the provisions of this chapter and any standards or rules, which may be established under its authority. The city is an at will employer. No provision in this chapter, and no standard, rule or policy which has been established pursuant to this chapter, creates any property interest in employment, and no employee has been conferred a property right to employment. Department directors and other designees of the city manager with authority to make appointments shall not make a direct or implied commitment to appoint any individual until all employment procedural and policy requirements have been satisfied in conjunction with the human resources office and in accordance with administrative policy. 
(Code 1964, § 2-18; Code 1982, § 14-3; Ord. No. 13408, § 1, 8-7-2006) 
Sec. 42-4. - Plan of position classification. 
    A plan of position classification is hereby established for all employees of the city. The city manager shall administer and maintain a current plan of position classification, and shall allocate and reallocate positions to classes on the basis of kind and level of duties and responsibilities. New classifications require approval by the council. Copies of the classification plan and amendments thereto shall be furnished to the members of the city council and to department directors, and shall be maintained on file in the offices of the city manager and city clerk. 
(Code 1964, § 2-19; Code 1982, § 14-4; Ord. No. 13408, § 1, 8-7-2006) 
Sec. 42-5. - Plan of position compensation. 
    A plan of position compensation is hereby established for all employees of the city. Salaries and wages of employees of the city are hereby fixed in pay grades established by the city council. The annual budget adopted by the city council and any amendments thereto, together with the authorized appropriations, shall constitute approval and control by the city council of salaries and wages. Copies of the compensation plan and amendments thereto shall be furnished to members of the city council and to department directors, and shall be maintained on file in the offices of the city manager and city clerk. 
(Code 1964, § 2-20; Code 1982, § 14-5; Ord. No. 13408, § 1, 8-7-2006; Ord. No. 13698, § 1, 9-15-2008) 
Sec. 42-6. - Probationary period for new and promoted employees. 
(a)  New employees and all promoted and transferred employees will serve a six-month probationary period. 
(b)  A new employee will not be considered a regular employee until successful completion of the probationary period as indicated by a completed performance evaluation with an overall rating of meets expectations or above. At that time, the employee will receive and be eligible to take one floating holiday. 
(c)  An employee may be separated during the six-month probationary period. A regular full-time employee who is promoted to a higher salary range may receive a pay increase upon promotion, in accordance with the compensation plan of the city. A promoted employee may be demoted. 
(d)  A six-month probationary period may be extended for an additional period of up to three months upon recommendation of the supervisor and approval of the department director. 
(Code 1964, § 2-20.1; Code 1982, § 14-6; Ord. No. 9209, § 1, 4-15-1991; Ord. No. 11028, § 2, 2-17-1997; Ord. No. 13408, § 1, 8-7-2006) 
Sec. 42-7. - Vacation. 
(a)  Vacation (annual leave) time with pay shall be earned by each full-time probationary, temporary-with-benefits, and full-time regular employee in accordance with the employee's length of service as follows: 
Length of service in years Leave hours earned per 26 bi-weekly pay period Employees who work 75 hours per

(b)  Vacation in excess of 240 hours (360 for sworn firefighters) on the record at the end of each calendar year is converted to an equivalent amount of sick leave at the end of the first full pay period which begins after January 1 in each calendar year. 
(c)  A full-time employee shall be able to take paid vacation (annual leave) as earned during the probationary period. 
(d)  An individual who leaves the employ of the city before successful completion of the probationary period is not eligible to be paid for accrued unused vacation. A regular full-time employee will forfeit pay for accrued vacation if that employee fails to give proper notice of his/her intention to resign. The length of notice required prior to resignation is as follows: 
Minimum prior notice 
required (Calendar weeks) Non-exempt employees (traditionally hourly paid employees) One week Professional, administrative employees Two weeks Division managers, department directors, and above Three weeks  
(e)  The city manager may grant additional vacation leave as a part of a salary negotiation for department directors and assistant or deputy city managers subject to approval of the city council or as a part of a council-approved incentive program. 
(Code 1964, § 2-21; Code 1982, § 14-7; Ord. No. 6142, §§ 1, 2, 6-20-1983; Ord. No. 7295, § 1, 8-17-1987; Ord. No. 9209, § 2, 4-15-1991; Ord. No. 9355, § 1, 7-23-1991; Ord. No. 13408, § 1, 8-7-2006; Ord. No. 14423, § 1, 4-1-2013; Ord. No. 14572, § 1, 2-3-2014) 
Sec. 42-8. - Sick leave. 
(a)  Sick leave is a benefit granted to the employee in the event of preventive health care, sickness, injury, disability, disability caused by pregnancy, serious illness in the immediate family or in the event of death in the immediate family. Immediate family includes spouse (or certified domestic partner), child, parent, brother, sister, grandparent and grandchild of the employee or the spouse (or certified domestic partner). 
    Sick leave with pay shall be earned by each full-time probationary, temporary-with-benefits, and full-time regular employee as follows: 
(1)  For employees who work 75 hours per pay period and sworn police officers: 3.692 hours per bi-weekly pay period. 
(2)  For employees who work 80 hours per pay period: 3.938 hours per bi-weekly pay period. 
(3)  For sworn firefighters: 5.538 hours per bi-weekly pay period. 
(b)  If sick leave is not used, it shall accrue without limit for as long as a person remains a full-time regular employee of the city. At retirement, the employee shall receive retirement credit for sick leave based on local government employees' retirement system regulations at the time of his/her retirement. Current regulations grant one month retirement credit for each 20 days of unusued sick leave plus an additional month for any part of 20 days left over. If an employee leaves city employment before retirement, sick leave is forfeited. 
(c)  A full-time regular employee who is eligible for retirement, and who remains absent from work for more than 60 consecutive workdays because of sickness or injury, shall file application for retirement. If the employee does not wish to retire, he/she shall demonstrate to the satisfaction of the director of human resources and the city manager in consultation with the department director and medical personnel, that his/her disability is not permanent. Employees who are unable to perform the essential functions of the job, even with accommodation, will be separated from city employment. 
(d)  Work week designations are those listed in the city compensation plan. 
(Code 1964, § 2-21; Code 1982, § 14-8; Ord. No. 9209, § 3, 4-15-1991; Ord. No. 9355, § 2, 7-23-1991; Ord. No. 10257, § 1, 8-1-1994; Ord. No. 13408, § 1, 8-7-2006; Ord. No. 14572, § 2, 2-3-2014) 
Sec. 42-9. - Longevity merit compensation. 
(a)  Longevity merit compensation (hereafter referred to as "longevity pay") will be paid in December to each employee who has completed five years of continuous full-time service on or before the first day of the preceding July, and was hired as a full time employee before July 1, 1998. The employee must be employed in a full time regular capacity on the date in December that longevity is paid in order to receive the payment for that year. A retiring employee who is no longer employed in December but otherwise meets all of the eligibility requirements for longevity shall receive a final longevity merit payment at the time of the final regular pay check in accordance with procedures established by the city manager. 
(b)  In order to receive longevity pay, the employee must have received an overall evaluation of "meets expectation" or higher during the most recent annual performance review; however: 
(1)  Longevity pay otherwise due to an employee who receives an overall evaluation rating of "does not meet expectations" shall be deferred pending a subsequent evaluation of the employee's performance three months after the initial unsatisfactory performance review. If at the three-month reevaluation the employee attains an overall rating of "meets expectations" or higher, the longevity pay shall be paid to the employee. 
(2)  Any employee who receives two consecutive overall ratings of "does not meet expectations" during the prior two performance review periods (including any extended period for subsequent evaluation) is not eligible for longevity pay. 
(c)  For the purposes of this section, "continuous full-time service" shall be defined as full-time employment without a break in service. A "break in service" occurs when an employee is rehired following resignation or discharge; provided however, when an employee is rehired within 60 days after a resignation which occurs on or after February 16, 1981 and before July 1, 1998, service shall be deemed to be continuous. 
(Code 1964, § 2-20.3; Code 1982, § 14-9; Ord. No. 5597, § 1, 2-16-1981; Ord. No. 5698, § 1, 6-15-1981; Ord. No. 5786A, § 1, 10-19-1981; Ord. No. 9209, § 4, 4-15-1991; Ord. No. 13408, § 1, 8-7-2006) 
Sec. 42-10. - Salary continuation and job disability with approval of workers' compensation. 
    Any employee who suffers a work-related injury or illness as defined under G.S. ch. 97 and, therefore, is absent from duty will be eligible for and paid benefits as defined in the Workers' Compensation Act. Employees eligible for such benefits under the Workers' Compensation Act will not be entitled to sick leave or vacation leave, except as provided herein. 
(1)  Beginning with the first day of disability, employees disabled on the job, and for whom workers' compensation is approved, shall receive regular net pay and be granted leave without charge against accrued sick leave or annual leave during the first seven calendar days of disability to compensate him or her for wages lost during the "waiting period" as defined in G.S. ch. 97. 
(2)  Pursuant to the Workers' Compensation Act, an employee who becomes eligible for temporary total disability or temporary partial disability benefits following the "waiting period" will receive benefits in accordance with the act and will also be eligible to use accrued sick, vacation, or compensatory leave to supplement their income up to the amount of their regular net pay. The employee shall first provide written authorization to use accrued leave for this purpose. In no event shall an employee receive a total of workers' compensation benefits plus partial salary that exceeds net income derived from regular work. 
(3)  In calculating the charge to accrued leave required to reach regular net pay, sworn law enforcement officers and firefighters shall receive a credit to accrued leave equivalent to five percent of the amount of workers' compensation paid for the work period; provided, that the five percent credit shall be a maximum necessary to reach regular net pay and shall not augment the balance of accrued leave. 
(4)  When either the employee does not so request or all accrued leave is exhausted before the period of disability and workers' compensation coverage is ended, the employee shall receive payment in accordance with the Workers' Compensation Act. 
(5)  For purposes of subsections (2) and (3) of this section, "regular net pay" means the greater of: (1) the amount of payment required under workers' compensation; or (2) the normal gross salary which would be due the employee for a work period minus deductions which are required by law to be made against such salary, including by way of illustration and not limitation, deductions for state and federal income taxes, social security (FICA), and payment into the Local Government Employees Retirement System. Any additional deductions authorized by the employee shall then be taken from the employee's regular net pay prior to issuance of a check by the city. 
(Code 1964, § 2-24; Code 1982, § 14-10; Ord. No. 5403, § 1, 6-19-1980; Ord. No. 5629, § 1, 4-6-1981; Ord. No. 7500, § 1, 5-16-1988; Ord. No. 12988, § I, 6-21-2004) 
Sec. 42-11. - Military leave. 
    Employees who are members of armed forces reserves or the National Guard may be granted leave with pay for military training for up to two calendar weeks per calendar year. Military leave in excess of the two weeks shall be leave of absence without pay unless otherwise recommended by the city manager and approved by city council. Military leave includes the amount of time reasonably necessary to travel to and from the military assignment, plus a minimum of eight hours for rest upon return if the active military service is less than 30 consecutive days, 14 days if between 31-180 days, and ninety days if more than 181 days of active military service. Advanced notice must be given to the employer unless precluded by military necessity, or the giving of notice is impossible or unreasonable. City employees using military leave are granted job rights and protections as prescribed by the Uniformed Services Employment and Reemployment Rights Act of 1994 (USERRA). 
(Code 1964, § 2-26; Code 1982, § 14-12; Ord. No. 13408, § 1, 8-7-2006) 
Sec. 42-12. - Civil leave. 
    Full-time regular employees are entitled to civil leave if necessary to serve as a witness or on a jury subject to policy authorized by the city manager. An employee required to be a witness or juror will receive his/her regular pay while on civil leave, even if such service may otherwise provide compensation. City employees who volunteer to serve as expert witnesses in litigation other than that in which the city is a party, are not entitled to use civil leave. 
(Code 1964, § 2-26.1; Code 1982, § 14-13; Ord. No. 9209, § 5, 4-15-1991; Ord. No. 13408, § 1, 8-7-2006) 
Sec. 42-13. - Retirement. 
(a)  Eligible city employees will be enrolled in the North Carolina Local Government Employees' Retirement System upon the first day of employment. 
(b)  A full-time regular city employee retires by application to the North Carolina Local Governmental Employees' Retirement System and selection of a monthly benefit, effective the first day of the month that he or she selects regardless of age, except as described in subsections (b) and (c) of this section. 
(c)  A full-time regular city employee must be able to demonstrate physical and mental competency to perform his or her position to the satisfaction of the director of human resources and the city manager in consultation with the department head and medical personnel. 
(d)  A full-time regular employee who is unable to effectively and safely perform in his or her position because of physical or mental disability (after reasonable accommodation has been considered) and who meets the eligibility requirements for service retirement, early retirement or disability retirement, will make official application for retirement on the first day of the month following the date of his or her disability. A full-time regular employee who remains absent from work for more than 60 consecutive workdays, because of injury or illness, shall file for retirement or shall show evidence, approved by the director of human resources and the city manager, in consultation with the department head and medical personnel, that his or her disability is not permanent. 
(e)  An employee who is unable to effectively and safely perform in his or her position because of physical or mental disability, and who does not meet the eligibility requirements for retirement, will be terminated from city employment, based on inability to effectively perform position requirements in accordance with city policy. 
(Code 1964, § 2-25.1; Code 1982, § 14-14; Ord. No. 5051, § 1, 12-4-1978; Ord. No. 6046, § 1, 12-20-1982; Ord. No. 6313, §§ 1-3, 2-6-1984; Ord. No. 7130, § 1, 1-20-1987; Ord. No. 9209, § 6, 4-15-1991; Ord. No. 11028, § 3, 2-17-1997) 
Sec. 42-14. - Special separation allowance for retired law enforcement officers. 
(a)  In accordance with the requirements set forth in G.S. 143-166.41 and 143-166.42, the city shall provide a special separation allowance to eligible retired law enforcement officers. 
(b)  The city manager shall establish necessary administrative procedures to ensure the criteria set forth in G.S. 143-166.41 and 143-166.42 are met. 
(c)  The city manager shall make determinations as to eligibility for the special separation allowance in accordance with the above named statutes. 
(Code 1982, § 14-14.1; Ord. No. 7788, § 1, 6-19-1989) 
Sec. 42-15. - Residence requirement for manager, attorney and clerk. 
    Any person employed by the city in the position of city manager, city attorney or city clerk shall be a resident of the city. The residence requirement of this section is met when a person meets the residence requirement of G.S. ch. 163 for the purpose of voting in the municipal elections of the city. Provided, however, any person who shall be appointed city manager, city attorney or city clerk who does not reside in the city at the time of such appointment, shall have a period of six months from and after such appointment to comply with the residence requirements of this section. This section shall not apply to any person serving in an acting or interim capacity. 
(Code 1964, § 2-20.2; Code 1982, § 14-15; Ord. No. 5278, § 2, 10-15-1979; Ord. No. 5460, § 1, 9-8-1980) 
Sec. 42-16. - City holidays. 
(a)  Legal holidays. Legal holidays observed by city government are New Year's Day, Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr., Day; Good Friday, Memorial Day, Independence Day, Labor Day, Thanksgiving Day, the day after Thanksgiving Day, Christmas Day; and such other times as may be authorized by action of the city council. Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr., Day will be observed on the third Monday of January, beginning in 1985. Veteran's Day will be observed beginning in 2016. 
(b)  Holiday observance. When a holiday other than Christmas falls on a Saturday, it shall be observed on the preceding Friday. When a holiday other than Christmas falls on a Sunday, it shall be observed on the following Monday. When Christmas Day falls on: 
(1)  A Monday, then Monday and Tuesday shall be observed as holidays; 
(2)  A Tuesday, then Monday, Tuesday and Wednesday shall be observed as holidays; 
(3)  A Wednesday, then Monday, Tuesday and Wednesday shall be observed as holidays; 
(4)  A Thursday, then Wednesday, Thursday and Friday shall be observed as holidays; 
(5)  A Friday, the Thursday and Friday shall be observed as holidays; 
(6)  A Saturday, then Friday and Monday shall be observed as holidays; 
(7)  A Sunday, then Friday and Monday shall be observed as holidays. 
(c)  Holidays shall equal: 
7.5 hours for full-time regular employees assigned to a 37.5-hour workweek; 
10.0 hours for full-time regular employees assigned to a 40-hour workweek; 
Other full-time regular employees as covered in subsection (d) of this section. Workweek designations are indicated in the city compensation plan. 
(d)  Holiday hours will granted as follows: 
7.5 hours for employees assigned to a 37.5-hour workweek; 
8.0 hours for employees assigned to a 40.0-hour workweek (5-day schedule); 
10.0 hours for employees assigned to a 40-hour workweek; 
12.0 hours for employees assigned to a 42-hour workweek; 
12.0 hours for employees assigned to a 56-hour workweek. 
Employees will receive holiday time equal to the hours in their normal workday schedule. Workweek designations are listed in the city compensation plan. 
(e)  Separation from employment. If an employee as described in subsection (d) of this section separates from employment prior to December 31, after using all holiday hours, a deduction for the legal holidays remaining will be made at the rates indicated in subsection (d) of this section. If an employee described in subsection (d) of this section separates from employment prior to December 31, without using holiday hours for legally observed holidays which have passed, he or she will be paid for unused, but past holiday hours, based on the rates indicated in subsection (d) of this section. No additional holiday hours shall be given. 
(f)  Holiday hours. Holiday hours shall not be carried over from one calendar year to the next. 
(g)  Administrative procedures and guidelines. For part-time/temporary employees who have worked for six consecutive months the holidays observed in subsection (a) of this section will be granted on a prorated basis. Administrative procedures and guidelines will be established by the city manager. 
(h)  Floating holiday. In addition to the legal holidays listed in subsection (a) of this section; one additional day, a floating holiday, may be observed by city employees. The city manager shall establish administrative procedures for the scheduling of floating holidays so as to ensure that city government services maintain normal operations. 
(Code 1982, § 14-16; Ord. No. 6141, § 1, 6-20-1983; Ord. No. 6383, § 1, 4-17-1984; Ord. No. 6813, § 1, 10-21-1985; Ord. No. 7289, § 1, 7-27-1987; Ord. No. 7714, § 1, 2-6-1989; Ord. No. 7846, § 1, 6-28-1989; Ord. No. 9209, § 7, 4-15-1991; Ord. No. 10257, § 2, 8-1-1994; Ord. No. 11770, § 1, 6-21-1999; Ord. No. 11859, § 1, 11-15-1999; Ord. No. 14973, § 1, 6-20-16) 
Sec. 42-17. - Effect of administrative procedures on legal entitlements. 
    No property rights with regard to benefits, termination or job status shall be inferred from policy memoranda, employee handbooks or other statements of administrative procedure unless such benefits or guarantees have been specifically and explicitly included in this chapter. 
(Code 1982, § 14-17; Ord. No. 9209, § 8, 4-15-1991) 
Sec. 42-18. - Employees to be paid livable wage. 
    Full-time city employees, and part-time city employees performing work that is commensurate with that of full-time classifications, shall be paid no less than the livable wage rate set according to section 18-23. The annual salary for sworn police officers and sworn fire employees, and for employees that have recruit status for either of those positions, will be equal to or greater than the annual rate set according to section 18-23. 
(Ord. No. 15012, § 3, 10-3-2016) 
Chapter 46 - PUBLIC SAFETY 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 46-1. - Equipment for decoding coded voice inversion messages; permission of city manager required for sale, use, etc. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person, without the written permission of the city manager, to sell, own, possess, or use any device, apparatus, or equipment, electronic or otherwise, capable of decoding coded voice inversion messages transmitted by transmitters at the city communications center. 
(b)  No written permission referred to in this section shall be granted by the city manager until the application for such permission has been approved by the city council. 
(Code 1964, § 13-5.1; Code 1982, § 12-3) 
Secs. 46-2-46-20. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - WEAPONS 

Sec. 46-21. - Discharging weapons-Generally. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person other than an officer authorized by law, or upon a range legally permitted by the chief of police, to discharge or shoot any firearm, pump gun, air rifle, air pistol, BB gun, crossbow, bow and arrow, slingshot, or any other weapon of like kind within the city. 
(b)  Subsection (a) shall not apply when the weapon is discharged or shot: 
(1)  In defense of person or property; 
(2)  Pursuant to the lawful directions of a law enforcement officer; 
(3)  In a city park for ceremonial or recreational purposes, provided that such person has first obtained, in writing, permission from the director of parks and recreation or his or her designee. In no event shall permission be given for the discharge of live ammunition; 
(4)  In a cemetery for the purpose of conducting a military or law enforcement funeral or commemorative exercise provided that such person has first obtained, in writing, permission from the city manager or his or her designee. In no event shall permission be given for the discharge of live ammunition; 
(5)  On state-designated game lands; or 
(6)  Pursuant to section 6-3, which permits deer archery within the city limits under specified circumstances. 
(Code 1964, § 13-29; Code 1982, § 12-20; Ord. No. 9738, § 1, 12-21-1992; Ord. No. 10065, §§ 1, 2, 2-7-1994; Ord. No. 14435, 4-15-2013; Ord. No. 14516, § 2, 11-4-2013) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 14435, adopted April 15, 2013, changed the title of section 46-21 from "Discharging firearms-Generally" to "Discharging weapons-Generally." The historical notation has been preserved for reference purposes. 
Charter reference- Authority to regulate, § 60. 
State Law reference- Authority to regulate, G.S. 160A-189. 
Sec. 46-22. - Display and possession of dangerous weapons-Prohibited on certain city property. 
(a)  It is unlawful for any person to display a dangerous weapon while on or in city property, or to leave displayed a dangerous weapon within a motor vehicle while the vehicle is on city property. Notwithstanding the foregoing, this section shall not prohibit the display of a long gun being stored in a locked gun rack in an attended motor vehicle, or a locked unattended motor vehicle, while the vehicle is on city property. 
(b)  The city manager, or his or her designee, may permit the posting of a prohibition against carrying a concealed handgun, in accordance with G.S. 14-415.11(c), on the city property identified below. The posting of a prohibition against carrying a concealed handgun at or within an athletic field shall only apply during an organized athletic event when the field has been scheduled for use with the city. Notwithstanding the foregoing, this section shall not prohibit a concealed handgun permittee from storing a handgun within the trunk, glove box, or other enclosed compartment or area within or on a locked motor vehicle while the vehicle is on city property. 
(1)  Any city building and its appurtenant premises; 
(2)  The following recreational facilities: 
a.  Each athletic field at or within: 
1.  C.M. Herndon Park located at 511 Scott King Road; 
2.  C.R. Wood Park located at 417 Commonwealth Avenue; 
3.  Campus Hills Park located at 2000 S. Alston Avenue; 
4.  Cook Road Park located at 602 Cook Road; 
5.  Crest Street Park located at 2503 Crest Street; 
6.  East Durham Park located at 2500 E. Main Street;

1.  Campus Hills Pool located at 2000 S. Alston Avenue;

1.  Edison Johnson Recreation Center located at 500 W. Murray Avenue; 
2.  W.D. Hill Recreation Center located at 1308 Fayetteville Street. 
(b)  For purposes of this section, the following words have the meaning indicated: 
    Athletic field means an outdoor area used for organized athletic events including any appurtenant facilities. 
    City property means any building including its grounds, park, recreational facility, playground, cemetery, landfill, parking garage, parking lot, streets, sidewalks, alleyways, or other public property owned by the city or leased by the city as lessee. City property does not include: property leased, subleased or rented by the city to a private person or entity; or ranges legally permitted by the chief of police. 
    Dangerous weapon means any firearm, pump gun, air rifle, air pistol, BB gun, crossbow, bow and arrow, bowie knife, dirk, dagger, slingshot, loaded cane, metallic knuckles, razor, shuriken, stun gun, switch blade knife, black jack, or any other weapon of like kind. 
    Handgun means a firearm that has a short stock and is designed to be held and fired by the use of a single hand. 
    Long gun means a shotgun or rifle which expels a projectile by action of an explosion. 
    Recreational facility means an athletic field, a swimming pool, or a facility used for athletic events. 
    Swimming pool means an artificially enclosed body of water intended for swimming or water-based recreation, including any appurtenant facilities used for dressing, storage of personal items, or other uses relating to the swimming pool. 
(c)  Conduct prohibited by this section shall not apply to: 
(1)  Sworn law enforcement officers who are within their jurisdiction; 
(2)  Members of the United States armed forces or national guard while in the discharge of their official duties; 
(3)  Any person possessing a dangerous weapon in a city cemetery for the purpose of conducting a military or law enforcement funeral or commemorative exercise pursuant to first having obtained written permission from the city manager or his or her designee; 
(4)  Any person possessing a dangerous weapon in a city park for ceremonial or recreational purposes pursuant to having first obtained valid written permission from the director of parks and recreation or his or her designee. 
(Code 1964, § 13-33; Code 1982, § 12-22; Ord. No. 9738, § 1, 12-21-1992; Ord. No. 10626, § 1, 11-6-1995; Ord. No. 11708, 6-7-1999; Ord. No. 14435, 4-15-2013; Ord. No. 14651, § 1, 6-16-2014)

The historical notation has been preserved for reference purposes. 
Secs. 46-23-46-27. - Reserved.

Sec. 46-28. - Penalties. 
    Violation of this article is a Class 3 misdemeanor, the maximum fine for which shall be $500.00. 
(Ord. No. 14435, 4-15-2013)
