(b)  It shall not be unlawful to beg or solicit alms or contributions except when performed in the following manner: 
(1)  In a public place by accosting another person or forcing oneself upon the company of another person; 
(2)  Within 20 feet of an entrance or exit of any bank or financial institution or within 20 feet of any automated teller machine; 
(3)  In any public transportation vehicle owned or operated by the city or at any terminal or station for such vehicle or within six feet of a stop for such vehicle; or 
(4)  In a public place during the time period that begins 20 minutes after sunset and ends 20 minutes before sunrise. For purposes of enforcement of this section, the terms "sunrise" and "sunset" shall be determined by and based on the times for those events published daily by the U.S. Naval Observatory Astronomical Applications Department. 
(Code 1982, § 12-28; Ord. No. 10186, § 1, 6-20-1994; Ord. No. 11950, § 1, 4-3-2000; Ord. No. 12948, § 1, 6-10-2004) 
ARTICLE VI. - CONTACT WITH AND INTRUSION INTO OCCUPIED VEHICLES ON ROADWAYS 

Sec. 54-262. - Purpose. 
    This article is intended to reduce the fear and intimidation that persons in motor vehicles feel when someone touches or intrudes into the vehicle without invitation or consent. 
(Ord. No. 14581, § 1, 2-20-2014) 
Sec. 54-263. - Definitions. 
    The definitions in section 54-26 for the following words are incorporated: occupant, motor vehicle, roadway, and tangible thing. 
    Enclosed vehicle means a motor vehicle, excluding every vehicle designed to run upon the streets that is pulled by a self-propelled vehicle. 
(Ord. No. 14581, § 1, 2-20-2014) 
Sec. 54-264. - Contact with and intrusion into occupied motor vehicle. 
    It is unlawful for a pedestrian to place a tangible thing or any part of his or her body on or inside an occupied enclosed vehicle that is on the roadway. This section is not intended to repeal or affect any other provision in this Code or any authority to act provided for by any other provision in this Code. This section does not apply: 
(1)  If the pedestrian has a right to possess, occupy, or use the vehicle, or the consent of a person with a right to possess, occupy, or use the vehicle; 
(2)  If the pedestrian has an ownership interest in the vehicle, or the consent of a person with an ownership interest in the vehicle; 
(3)  If an occupant requests that the pedestrian take that action or consents to the taking of the action; or if an occupant requests that the pedestrian deliver the tangible thing to an occupant or consents to such delivery; or if an occupant requests that the pedestrian receive a tangible thing from an occupant or consents to receiving it; 
(4)  To the following persons while engaged in the performance of their respective occupations: 
a.  Persons authorized by a governmental person to take the action; or 
b.  Firefighting personnel, law enforcement personnel, EMS personnel, health care workers or providers, military personnel, civil preparedness personnel, emergency management personnel, or emergency management workers (defined by G.S. 166A-19.60(e)); 
(5)  To the extent that firefighting personnel, law enforcement personnel, EMS personnel, health care workers or providers, military personnel, civil preparedness personnel, emergency management personnel, or emergency management workers (defined by G.S. 166A-19.60(e)) direct otherwise for the purpose of promoting safety of persons or property or to address an emergency; or 
(6)  To actions taken in response to an emergency. 
(Ord. No. 14581, § 1, 2-20-2014) 
Chapter 58 - SOLID WASTE COLLECTION AND DISPOSAL[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference- Authority to require owner to remove trash, etc., § 63; removal of abandoned vehicles from private property, § 55. 
State Law reference- Authority to regulate, G.S. 160A-192, 160A-303.1, 160A-311 et seq.; solid waste management, G.S. 130A-290 et seq.; abatement of public health nuisances, G.S. 160A-193; littering, G.S. 14-399. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 58-1. - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this chapter, the following terms shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them: 
    Ashes means the residue from the burning of wood, coal, coke and other combustible material in homes, stores, institutions and small commercial establishments and industrial plants, which are produced as the result of heating, cooking and disposing of combustible waste material. Ashes are usually composed of a mixture of fine powdery residue, some cinders and clinkers and small portions of unburned or partially burned fuel or other material. At times ashes might include small quantities of glass, crockery, sweepings, dust, metal, brick and other inorganic materials. Ashes will also include residue from household refuse incinerators and from yard rubbish burners as well as the remains from burning leaves and yard rubbish in open fires. Cinders and clinkers include large residue from the burning of coal and coke as produced from larger furnaces such as steam-generator plants or large heating furnaces. 
    Building rubbish means waste material resulting from construction, remodeling, repairs and demolition operations on houses, commercial buildings and other structures, including driveways and walks, and it comprises waste and rejected matter such as excavated earth, stones, bricks, plaster, wallpaper, sheetrock and lathes, lumber, shingles, tile, concrete and waste parts occasioned by the installation or replacement of plumbing, heating systems, electrical work and roofing. 
    Chapter, when used in any article in this chapter, refers to those provisions of this chapter. 
    Combustible rubbish means any burnable materials such as paper, rags, cartons, cardboard and wooden boxes, wood, excelsior wood, furniture, bedding, leather, rubber, tree branches, yard trimmings, sawdust, leaves, linoleum, plastics and the like. 
    Department means the department of solid waste management or its administrative successor. 
    Director means the director of the department or his or her designee. 
    Disposal area means the area where refuse is unloaded from collection trucks, either a landfill, rubble landfill, compost facility or a transfer station. 
    Garbage means the animal and vegetable waste resulting from the handling, preparation, cooking and serving of foods; garbage being composed largely of putrescible organic matter and its natural moisture content and originating primarily in home kitchens, stores, markets, restaurants, hotels, hospitals, or other places where food is stored, prepared or served. The term "garbage" shall not include liquid that may be drained into the sewer. 
    Household trash means any waste accumulation of paper, sweepings, dust, rags, bottles, discarded toys, small appliances, cans or other material of similar kind other than garbage, which is usually attendant to housekeeping. 
    Industrial refuse means solid waste materials, from factories, processing plants, wholesale establishments, assembling plants or shops and garages, such as: paper, cardboard, cartons, food processing wastes, cinders and ashes, lumber scraps, sawdust, excelsior, shavings, floor sweepings, metal scrap and shavings, glass and other waste products. 
    Litter means any discarded or abandoned, used or unconsumed substance or waste, including, but not limited to: garbage, trash, refuse, debris, rubbish, lawn and garden waste, newspaper, magazines, glass, metal, plastic or paper containers or other packaging, construction debris, motor vehicle parts, furniture, oil and dead animals. 
    Noncombustible rubbish means materials such as metals, tin cans, metal furniture, dirt, glass, crockery, ashes and cinders mineral matter, etc., that will not burn in the incinerator at the ordinary operating temperatures of from 1,250 degrees to 2,000 degrees Fahrenheit. 
    Person in default means a person required by state law, this Code, resolution of council, department policy, or as ordered by a court of competent jurisdiction, to perform or not to perform an act, and who fails to comply with that requirement. 
    Recyclables means materials that can be converted into component materials for the manufacture of new products. 
    Refuse means all classifications of solid waste, and shall include garbage, rubbish, ashes, cinders, street refuse, dead animals, abandoned automobiles and industrial refuse. Refuse derives from such places as homes, hotels, institutions, stores, restaurants, markets, wholesalers, processing plants, factories, shops, garages, office buildings, streets, sidewalks, alleys, vacant lots, power plants and the like. 
    Rubbish means combustible rubbish and noncombustible rubbish. 
    Street refuse means both combustible and noncombustible materials such as street sweepings, dirt, leaves, catchbasin collections, grass trimmings, contents of litter receptacles and glass. 
    Target recyclables means materials, declared as target recyclables by written policy of the director, that can be converted into component materials for the manufacture of new products and that have a stable market which assures that the materials will be sold and will not need to be stored or disposed. 
    Tipping fee means a monetary charge levied per ton for the disposal of garbage, yard waste, or other types of waste at a city disposal area. 
    Transfer station means a facility that allows for the unloading of solid waste so that it can be put in large trailers or containers and transported to a sanitary landfill. 
    Yard rubbish means tree branches, stumps, twigs, grass and shrub trimmings, bushes, weeds, leaves and general yard and garden waste materials and shall include stone and dirt rakings and any waste materials resulting from landscaping. 
    Yard waste means tree branches, twigs, grass and shrub trimmings, bushes, weeds, leaves and general yard and garden waste materials. 
(Code 1964, § 9-1; Code 1982, § 10-1; Ord. No. 7000, § 1(a), (b), 6-26-1986; Ord. No. 9518, § 1, 4-6-1992; Ord. No. 11287, § 1, 11-3-1997; Ord. No. 13263, § 2, 6-5-2006) 
Sec. 58-2. - Rules and regulations. 
    The director, subject to the approval of the city manager, shall have the authority to establish rules and regulations, consistent with the provisions of this chapter, governing the keeping, collection, removal and disposal of refuse and the maintenance and operation of the landfill area. Included, without limitation, are rules and regulations pertaining to remedial activities and civil enforcement, including collection and disposition of city or personal property located on city or other public property or right-of-way in violation of this chapter or rule or regulation established under this section, and that designate the size and type of container, location of collection, frequency of collection, types of refuse separation and other types of refuse or recyclable material collections. It shall be unlawful for any person to fail, neglect or refuse to comply with such rules and regulations. 
(Code 1964, § 9-2; Code 1982, § 10-2; Ord. No. 9486, § 1, 1-21-1992; Ord. No. 13263, § 2, 6-5-2006) 
Sec. 58-3. - Persons authorized to haul away refuse and recyclables set out for collection. 
    No person other than a person under the authority of the director shall haul away any refuse or recyclables set out for collection by the city. 
(Code 1964, § 9-3; Code 1982, § 10-3; Ord. No. 11287, § 2, 11-3-1997) 
Sec. 58-4. - Approval of vehicles used for private hauling. 
    In the event a person contracts for the private hauling of refuse within the city, such hauler shall first obtain the approval of the county health department as to the safe and sanitary condition of the vehicles used for hauling. 
(Code 1964, § 9-4; Code 1982, § 10-4) 
Sec. 58-5. - Disposition within city of refuse by haulers. 
    Persons hauling garbage and refuse shall be subject to the direction of the director and of the county health department as to the disposal of refuse within the city. 
(Code 1964, § 9-5; Code 1982, § 10-5) 
Sec. 58-6. - Allowing dog to run loose and turn over garbage and refuse containers. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to permit or allow his or her dog to run loose on regularly scheduled days on which garbage and refuse is collected upon collection routes so as to result in such dog's turning over, spilling and scattering the contents of refuse containers. 
(Code 1964, § 9-6; Code 1982, § 10-6) 
Sec. 58-7. - Remedial activities. 
(a)  The department shall have the authority to perform a remedial activity in any of the following instances: 
(1)  To execute an order of abatement in a civil action pursuant to section 1-9 and G.S. 160A-175; 
(2)  To summarily remove, abate, or remedy a condition, pursuant to G.S. 160A-193 and as authorized hereby, that is dangerous or prejudicial to the public health or safety; or 
(3)  To remove, abate, or remedy a condition that violates a provision of this chapter or rule or regulation established under section 58-2 and that is detrimental to the public health or safety, the environment, or citizen quality of life. 
(b)  The department shall have the authority to require that a person in default of legal obligations reimburse the department for costs and expenses in any instance where the department performs a remedial activity in response to such default. Such costs and expenses may be the actual costs incurred by the city to remedy the default, or standardized allocations of the city's remedial costs. 
(Ord. No. 13263, § 1(10-7), 6-5-2006) 
Sec. 58-8. - Civil enforcement; criminal enforcement prohibited. 
(a)  Whenever in this chapter or rule or regulation established under section 58-2 any act is prohibited or declared unlawful or any act is required or failure to perform the act is declared unlawful, the violation of such provision shall subject the violator to a remedial fee as established by resolution of city council. 
(b)  Any provision of this chapter or rule or regulation established under section 58-2 may be enforced by an appropriate equitable remedy issuing from a court of competent jurisdiction. In such case, the general court of justice shall have jurisdiction to issue such orders as may be appropriate, and it shall not be a defense to the application of the city for equitable relief that there is an adequate remedy at law. 
(c)  Any provision of this chapter or rule or regulation established under section 58-2 making unlawful a condition existing upon or use made of real property may be enforced by injunction and order of abatement. The general court of justice shall have jurisdiction to issue such orders and such actions shall proceed pursuant to G.S. 160A-175(e). Where the city executes an order of abatement, the lien and any cancellation of the order of abatement shall constitute costs and expenses under section 58-7(a). 
(d)  Any provision of this chapter or rule or regulation established under section 58-2 may be enforced by any one, all, or a combination of the remedies authorized and prescribed by this section and the remedial activities authorized and prescribed by section 58-7. 
(e)  Except as otherwise provided, each day of any violation of any provision of this chapter or rule or regulation established under section 58-2 shall constitute a separate and distinct offense. 
(f)  Criminal enforcement of any violation of any provision of this chapter or rule or regulation established under section 58-2 is hereby prohibited. Any such violation does not constitute a misdemeanor or other criminal violation. Any such provision may be enforced only through one or more civil actions authorized by this section. 
(Ord. No. 13263, § 1(10-8), 6-5-2006) 
Sec. 58-9. - Solid waste enforcement personnel. 
    The director or director's designee shall have the authority to pursue remedial activities or enforce any provision of this chapter or rule or regulation established under section 58-2, pursuant to rules established under section 58-2. 
(Ord. No. 13263, § 1(10-9), 6-5-2006) 
Sec. 58-10. - Administrative review process. 
    Any person who receives notice of imposition of a cost, expense, or fee under section 58-7(a)(3) or 58-8(a) and (e) may obtain review by written request to the director, which must be received by the department within ten calendar days of provision of notice. Within 30 calendar days of receipt, the director shall review the request and render a written decision maintaining or withdrawing, in whole or in part, the cost, expense, or fee imposed, which shall be the final decision of the city. Such decision, or absence of a request for review under this subsection, shall constitute exhaustion of the department's administrative review process. E-mail communication shall constitute written communication for purposes of this section. 
(Ord. No. 13263, § 1(10-10), 6-5-2006) 
Sec. 58-11. - Recovery and retention of remediation costs and expenses and remedial fees. 
(a)  Costs, expenses, and fees imposed under sections 58-7 and 58-8 shall be remitted to and retained by the department. 
(b)  Owners and occupants of real property are responsible for costs, expenses, and fees relating to that property. The department may obtain payment from owners or occupants as appropriate or necessary. 
(c)  Costs, expenses, and fees not remitted to the department within 30 calendar days after provision of notice or exhaustion of the administrative review process, whichever is later, may appear on the combined utility bill of the person in default under section 58-7 or the violator under section 58-8 and shall receive the same payment priority as other department charges. 
(d)  Costs, expenses, and fees not remitted to the department within 30 calendar days after provision of notice or exhaustion of the administrative review process, whichever is later, may be recovered in a civil action in the nature of debt if recovery under subsection (c) of this section is inapplicable. 
(e)  Interest on any unpaid cost, expense, or fee shall accrue at the rate of one percent per month and be incorporated into that cost, expense, or fee. 
(f)  If a cost or expense incurred under section 58-7(b) is not paid as required, it shall constitute a lien pursuant to G.S. 160A-193. 
(Ord. No. 13263, § 1(10-11), 6-5-2006) 
Secs. 58-12-58-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - RECEPTACLES 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 58-31. - Householders, stores, etc., to provide. 
    All householders, stores, institutions, restaurants markets, hotels, and other places where refuse is collected shall provide proper receptacles as defined in the rules and regulations established pursuant to section 58-2, unless a receptacle is provided by the city. 
(Code 1964, § 9-8; Code 1982, § 10-20; Ord. No. 9486, § 2, 1-21-1992) 
Sec. 58-32. - Types of garbage collection service provided. 
    The director shall provide roll-out garbage collection and sanitary bulk container garbage collection service. 
(Code 1982, § 10-21; Ord. No. 11283, § 2, 10-20-1997) 
Sec. 58-33. - Construction; covers and handles. 
    Receptacles shall be made substantially of metal or plastic; watertight and provided with tight-fitting covers and strong handles. 
(Code 1964, § 9-10; Code 1982, § 10-22) 
Sec. 58-34. - Replacement when defective, etc. 
    Any receptacle that does not otherwise conform to the provisions of this chapter or that has ragged or sharp edges or other defects liable to hamper or injure the persons collecting the contents thereof shall not be used for holding yard waste or any other material intended for collection, but shall be promptly replaced, on notice by the director, by a proper receptacle as a condition to collection of the contents of that receptacle. 
(Code 1964, § 9-12; Code 1982, § 10-24; Ord. No. 9518, § 2, 4-6-1992) 
Sec. 58-35. - Construction of garbage receptacles to prevent entrance of flies. 
    All receptacles for garbage shall, at all times, be so constructed and maintained and so covered as to prevent the entrance of flies. 
(Code 1964, § 9-13; Code 1982, § 10-25) 
Sec. 58-36. - Damage to roll-out refuse carts and recycling bins. 
(a)  Prohibition. It shall be unlawful for any person to deliberately set fire to, put hot ashes in, drive over, crack or otherwise damage or destroy a roll-out refuse cart or recycling bin that has been provided by the city. 
(b)  Civil penalty. Any person who violates this section shall be assessed a civil penalty of $100.00 plus the cost of replacing the roll-out cart or recycling bin for each violation. 
(c)  Assessment. The director of sanitation shall assess civil penalties under this section. 
(d)  Appeal. Any person who has been assessed a civil penalty under this section may request, orally or in writing, a hearing with the city manager. The request for a hearing shall be filed in the city manager's office within ten days of the issuance of the notice of assessment. The city manager shall schedule a hearing within 30 days from the date the request is filed. The decision of the city manager shall be final. Failure to perfect an appeal within the time and in the manner provided for in this section shall constitute a waiver of the right to appeal. 
(e)  Criminal. Any person who violates this section shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. The maximum fine shall be $100.00 and the maximum term of imprisonment shall be 30 days. 
(Code 1982, § 10-29; Ord. No. 9518, § 3, 4-6-1992; Ord. No. 13263, § 2, 6-5-2006) 
Sec. 58-37. - Centralized roll-out cart service. 
    The director may, upon written request, authorize one or more suitable centralized locations for roll-out cart garbage collection service to single family detached subdivision which qualifies for roll-out cart service. The subdivision must provide an adequate area, subject to the director's approval, for such centralized pick-up. The director will set the maximum number of roll-out carts for such an arrangement on a case-by-case basis. 
(Code 1982, § 10-30; Ord. No. 11283, § 3, 10-20-1997) 
Sec. 58-38. - Stationary container service to qualified housing units. 
(a)  Where housing units qualify under city ordinances for roll-out cart solid waste collection service and the housing units instead request under section 58-66(6) to be served by stationary containers in accordance with city ordinances and regulations, if the request is approved, such service will be provided with the same frequency as the city provides roll-out cart service without charging any fees for such collections, other than the fees which may be applicable to roll-out cart service. 
(b)  Frequency of service will be as necessary to reasonably serve the housing units, as determined by the director of solid waste or the director's designee, with usual and customary service of one collection per week. 
(c)  Housing units qualifying for stationary container service under this section shall be responsible for providing a suitable stationary container which complies with the provisions of this chapter and all applicable rules and regulations of the city. The placement of stationary containers for collection service by the city must be approved by the director of solid waste or the director's designee. The provisions of division 2 shall apply to all housing units to be served by stationary containers. Where the term "unit ownership (condominium)" appears in division 2, it shall be interpreted to include all housing units approved for stationary container service under this section. 
(Code 1982, § 10-31; Ord. No. 11563, § 1, 9-8-1998) 
Charter reference- Authority to provide stationary container service to qualified housing units, § 38. 
Secs. 58-39-58-64. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - STATIONARY BULK REFUSE CONTAINERS 

Sec. 58-65. - Mandatory use of stationary containers. 
    Each collection of garbage from a stationary container shall be for a fee, as set by the city council, except as provided in section 58-38 for service to qualified housing units. The following locations must be served by a stationary container rather than roll-out carts: 
(1)  Customers who generate more refuse between pickups than the capacity of four roll-out carts. 
(2)  Clustered or attached residences, including apartments, townhouses and condominiums, as described in section 58-66. 
(3)  Any location to which access is denied to city equipment and personnel, or where streets will not support city equipment without the risk of damage, or which the director determines may not be served efficiently due to design or other factors. 
(4)  Commercial developments in which four or more businesses operate from the same site or location. 
(Code 1982, § 10-34; Ord. No. 11283, § 4, 10-20-1997; Ord. No. 11563, § 2, 9-8-1998) 
Sec. 58-66. - Required; specifications. 
    Owners of townhouse and unit ownership (condominium) developments, as defined in the UDO, owners or occupants of housing units choosing to be served by stationary container service provided by the city under section 58-38, and owners of residential apartment buildings or of a group of residence apartment buildings in the same complex wherein there are more than four living units either in a single building or in the complex treated as a unit, are hereby required to install and maintain for each townhouse or unit ownership (condominium) development or grouping of housing units and for each residence apartment building which contains more than four living units, and for each residence apartment group or complex which group or complex contains in the aggregate more than four living units, stationary bulk refuse containers according to the following specifications: 
(1)  A minimum four cubic yards capacity stationary bulk refuse container for each townhouse or unit ownership (condominium) development and for each residence apartment building which contains more than four and fewer than 13 living units, and for each residence apartment group or complex which group or complex contains in the aggregate more than four and fewer than 13 living units. 
(2)  A minimum six cubic yards capacity stationary bulk refuse container for each townhouse or unit ownership (condominium) development and for each residence apartment building which contains more than 12 and fewer than 17 living units, and for each residence apartment group or complex which group or complex contains in the aggregate more than 12 and fewer than 17 living units. 
(3)  A minimum eight cubic yards capacity stationary bulk refuse container for each townhouse or unit ownership (condominium) development and for each residence apartment building which contains more than 16 and fewer than 31 living units, and for each residence apartment group or complex which group or complex contains in the aggregate more than 16 and fewer than 31 living units. 
(4)  Where a townhouse or unit ownership (condominium) development, a residence apartment building or a residence apartment group or complex contains in excess of 30 living units, additional stationary bulk refuse containers are required to be installed and maintained as a minimum in the same ratio as herein set forth in subsections (1), (2) and (3) of this section for the living units in excess of 30. By way of example of the application of the ratio herein intended: For a townhouse or unit ownership (condominium) development, or a residence apartment building or a residence apartment group or complex containing 35 living units, a minimum of one eight-cubic-yard container and one four-cubic-yard container is required; for 43 to 46 living units, a minimum of one eight-cubic-yard container and one six-cubic-yard container is required; for 47 to 59 living units, a minimum of one eight-cubic-yard container, one six-cubic-yard container and one four-cubic-yard container is required; and for living units in excess of 59, the same ratio will apply. 
(5)  The provisions of this section shall not apply to any developer, homeowners' association exercising control or ownership of the development, or other successor to the control and interest of the developer of a townhouse development conforming to the definition of townhouse or unit ownership (condominium) development set forth in the UDO who, prior to the effective date of this subsection, elected to have such development served by individual containers at each dwelling unit rather than by stationary bulk containers. 
(6)  Should the developer, homeowners' association or other successor to the interest of the developer referred to in subsection (5) of this section desire to install and maintain stationary bulk refuse containers and abandon the use of individual containers at each dwelling unit, it should make a written request for such a change in form of refuse collection to the city manager. The city shall bear no expense for alterations or improvements, such as the installation of concrete pads or upgraded paving, that may be required by the city manager in order to provide the requested service. In addition, the city manager, in his or her discretion and after full review of available city resources and the demands of the request, may delay the provision of the requested service up to six months after approval of the request or until the beginning of the next fiscal year, whichever is longer. 
(7)  The provisions of this section related to townhouse and unit ownership (condominium) developments apply only to townhouse and unit ownership (condominium) developments that are restricted to residential use by declaration and are so used for residential purposes. 
(8)  Owners may satisfy the minimum cubic yards capacity requirement under this section by either installing and maintaining a stationary bulk refuse container having the minimum cubic yards capacity required in subsections (1), (2), (3) and (4) of this section or by installing and maintaining both a stationary bulk refuse container and a recycling container having a combined cubic yards capacity which equals the required minimum cubic yards capacity required in subsections (1), (2), (3) and (4) of this section. 
(Code 1964, § 9-16.1; Code 1982, § 10-35; Ord. No. 5902, §§ 1-13, 3-15-1982; Ord. No. 9518, §§ 4-7, 4-6-1992; Ord. No. 11563, § 3, 9-8-1998) 
Sec. 58-67. - Applicability of division to new construction. 
    All of the provisions of section 58-66 shall apply to all new construction, alteration or conversion of residential apartment buildings and residential apartment groups or complexes for which any building permit shall be or has been issued after March 2, 1970, where the residence apartment building or residence apartment group or complex of buildings will contain more than four living units; and no building permit shall be issued after March 2, 1970, for construction, alteration or conversion of a building or group or complex of buildings falling within the application of this division unless and until a plan approved in writing by the director as showing adequate provision for installation of containerization of refuse as required by this division shall be furnished by the owner or developer; and no such residence apartment building or group or complex of residence apartment buildings to which this division applies shall be constructed, altered or converted after March 2, 1970, without providing for the use and maintenance of stationary bulk refuse containers as required by this division. 
(Code 1964, § 9-16.2; Code 1982, § 10-36) 
Sec. 58-68. - Location. 
    The location of required stationary bulk refuse containers shall be so as to permit convenient and safe access by the servicing truck and equipment using all-weather streets or alleys of adequate strength, to minimize as far as reasonably permitted excessive walking distances for tenants and occupants and to be as aesthetically pleasing as the circumstances will reasonably allow, in order to conveniently permit servicing of such stationary bulk refuse containers upon a collection schedule approved by the director. Any recycling containers on the property shall also be located in such a place so as to permit convenient and safe access to them by the servicing truck and equipment. 
(Code 1964, § 9-16.4; Code 1982, § 10-38; Ord. No. 9518, § 9, 4-6-1992) 
Sec. 58-69. - Variances; appeals. 
(a)  Where unnecessary hardship or inequities are created by the strict enforcement of the letter of this division, the director is authorized, after hearing, to grant reasonable variances and extensions, in harmony with the overall intent and purpose of this division, so that the spirit and objectives of this division may be carried out and substantial justice done, and at the same time unnecessary expense and inconvenience to the owners and occupants of the apartments be kept at a permissible minimum. 
(b)  Notwithstanding any other provision of this division, owners of residential apartment buildings may apply to the director for exemption from the requirements of this division. When such an owner by written application agrees to provide garbage collection service to buildings owned by him or her which is equal or superior to the service furnished by the city, the director may, in the exercise of his or her judgment, waive the other requirements of this division. The director will prescribe the form of application to require such information as will enable him or her to ascertain that the occupants of the buildings affected will receive garbage service which is consistent with that rendered by the city. Should the director determine that the garbage collection service rendered under a waiver is inadequate, he or she will revoke the waiver by giving the owner written notice 30 days in advance of the effective date of such revocation. Upon such revocation, the owner shall comply with the other sections of this division as if no waiver had ever been granted. 
(c)  Any person who is dissatisfied with any ruling or order of the director may appeal to the city council, which is hereby designated as the appeal board, and the city council may sustain or reverse the action, or modify same or remand for further hearing; provided, that any such appeal shall be in writing and signed by the owner of the property as to which the appeal is taken, or by his or her attorney, stating in a considered manner the grounds upon which the appeal is based, and filed with the city clerk not later than ten days after the rendition of the decision or order appealed. Unless such appeal is perfected in the manner and within the time herein specified, the action of the director shall be considered final. In computing the ten-day period herein provided, Saturdays, Sundays, New Year's Day, Good Friday, Independence Day, Labor Day, Thanksgiving Day and Christmas Day shall be excluded; the day upon which the decision appealed is given shall be excluded; and the tenth countable day thereafter (after the specified exclusions) shall be included. 
(Code 1964, § 9-16.6; Code 1982, § 10-39) 
Secs. 58-70-58-96. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - PREPARATION, ETC., OF REFUSE AND RECYCLABLES FOR COLLECTION 

Sec. 58-97. - Wrapping and draining garbage; refuse allowed in garbage receptacle; source separation of recyclables. 
    All garbage placed in receptacles shall be wrapped or contained in bags and shall be drained and free of wastewater. No liquids, except natural moisture contents of garbage, shall be placed in receptacles. Recyclables shall be properly prepared, separated from garbage and placed into a separate bin for collection. Recyclables shall not be put in the garbage receptacle. 
(Code 1964, § 9-17; Code 1982, § 10-50; Ord. No. 9518, § 10, 4-6-1992; Ord. No. 11287, 11-3-1997) 
Sec. 58-98. - Yard waste. 
    Yard waste will not be collected by the city or disposed of at the city landfill area if it is in plastic bags, plastic wrappers, or plastic sheets. Yard waste will not be collected by the city unless it is contained in biodegradable paper bags designed and marketed for yard waste, provided that such bags shall be subject to type, size, and closure restrictions and requirements as may be made pursuant to section 58-2; or set out in such receptacles or in such other manner as may be permitted by rules and regulations made pursuant to section 58-2. Notwithstanding the previous sentence, tree and shrub trimmings may be collected if set out pursuant to the preceding sentence or if they are securely tied in bundles which do not exceed four feet in length, 18 inches in diameter, and 75 pounds in weight, and which do not contain any single piece of wood exceeding six inches in diameter. 
(Code 1982, § 10-55) 
Sec. 58-99. - Large tree and shrub trimmings, excessive amounts of refuse. 
    Large tree and shrub trimmings, bulky and excessive amounts of refuse, leaves and yard rakings that cannot be handled by routine collection procedure will be handled under regulations of the director, at the owner's request, for a fee to cover actual cost. This is referred to as "extra refuse" and will be hauled by the department as soon as conveniently possible, but such hauling shall not interfere with the normal collection schedule of regular refuse and garbage. Tree stumps, trunks and limbs shall be cut to sizes that can readily be loaded by two adult persons, and shall be piled in easily accessible locations for loading. This section shall not be construed to apply to material the disposition of which is referred to in section 58-154. 
(Code 1964, § 9-22; Code 1982, § 10-56) 
Sec. 58-100. - Unauthorized use of bulk refuse containers. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to place material in a bulk refuse container situated upon private property unless such person owns or occupies the property, or is an employee or agent of such owner or occupant, or has been given written permission by the owner or occupant to use such container. 
(Code 1964, § 9-19.2; Code 1982, § 10-57; Ord. No. 5369, § 1, 4-21-1980; Ord. No. 13263, § 2, 6-5-2006) 
Sec. 58-101. - Animal litter. 
    Animal litter will be collected provided such is wrapped in newspaper and placed in a plastic bag that is securely tied and placed at the curbside on scheduled collection days. 
(Code 1982, § 10-58; Ord. No. 7841, § 2, 6-28-1989) 
Sec. 58-102. - Hypodermic needles. 
    Hypodermic syringes and needles will be collected provided such is placed in a plastic puncture resistant carton with a tightfitting lid and placed at the curbside on scheduled collection days. 
(Code 1982, § 10-59; Ord. No. 7841, § 3, 6-28-1989) 
Sec. 58-103. - Separate receptacles for recyclables. 
    Separate receptacles shall be used for the set out of recyclable materials that are collected by the city, or by the city's contractor. 
(Code 1982, § 10-59.1; Ord. No. 9518, § 16, 4-6-1992) 
Sec. 58-104. - Use of "drop-off" containers. 
    Recycling "drop-off" centers situated throughout the city and marked for recyclable materials may be used only for the depositing of recyclable materials collected by the city or by the city's contractor. It shall be unlawful for any person to place any materials in such containers except clean recyclable materials. 
(Code 1982, § 10-59.2; Ord. No. 9518, § 17, 4-6-1992) 
Sec. 58-105. - Use of stationary containers reserved for recyclables. 
    All stationary containers reserved for recyclables, such as corrugated cardboard, glass, and plastics, shall be used for recyclable materials only. It shall be unlawful for other types of refuse to be placed in these stationary containers. There shall be a fee, established by action of the city council, assessed to businesses that mix refuse in with recyclables. 
(Code 1982, § 10-59.3; Ord. No. 11287, § 5, 11-3-1997) 
Secs. 58-106-58-123. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - REMOVAL, DISPOSITION, ETC. 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 58-124. - Generally. 
    Garbage, rubbish and ashes, when stored in proper receptacles outside of buildings and placed in accessible locations, shall be removed under regulations of the director, subject to the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1964, § 9-23; Code 1982, § 10-60) 
Sec. 58-125. - Collection schedules. 
(a)  Collection schedules shall be as determined by the director of solid waste. The director or the director's designee shall have the authority to alter collection schedules to observe holidays or to meet emergency situations. 
(b)  Businesses that generate more than two cubic yards of refuse each week, which equals approximately the capacity of four roll-out carts, must install and maintain a stationary bulk refuse container. 
(Code 1964, § 9-23.1; Code 1982, § 10-61; Ord. No. 5496, § 1, 10-21-1980; Ord. No. 9518, § 18, 4-6-1992; Ord. No. 11283, § 5, 10-20-1997; Ord. No. 11563, § 4, 9-8-1998) 
Sec. 58-126. - Placing and storing of refuse outside of buildings. 
    Refuse of all classes shall be placed and stored outside of buildings at easily accessible locations. 
(Code 1964, § 9-24; Code 1982, § 10-62) 
Sec. 58-127. - Locations at which business houses to set out refuse containers. 
    All business houses such as stores, markets, food serving establishments, institutions and any other businesses that have collections made by the city, shall set out their containers of refuse at locations prescribed by the director. 
(Code 1964, § 9-25; Code 1982, § 10-63) 
Sec. 58-128. - Duty of collectors as to receptacles. 
    All refuse collectors shall exercise all reasonable care in handling receptacles and shall not willfully break, deface or injure such receptacles. 
(Code 1964, § 9-26; Code 1982, § 10-64) 
Sec. 58-129. - Responsibility for kitchen utensils, etc., used as waste receptacles. 
    The city and its employees shall not be responsible for any kitchen utensil, kitchen waste can or other article of value used for a waste receptacle or otherwise placed with regular refuse containers for the collectors to handle. 
(Code 1964, § 9-27; Code 1982, § 10-65) 
Sec. 58-130. - Receptacles on streets. 
    No private refuse receptacle of any kind shall be placed or remain upon any public street or sidewalk, on Sunday or on any other day that is not a collection day, or otherwise than as prescribed by the director or as prescribed herein. 
(Code 1964, §§ 9-28, 9-31; Code 1982, § 10-66) 
State Law reference- Location by city of containers on highways, G.S. 136-18.3. 
Sec. 58-131. - Collection in certain areas. 
(a)  Hours for depositing refuse. It shall be unlawful for any person to place or cause to be placed or deposited upon any of the streets, sidewalks or thoroughfares described and set forth in section 58-131, whether in a receptacle or otherwise, any trash, rubbish, wastepaper, refuse or garbage, at any time except between the hours of 6:30 a.m. and 9:00 a.m. 
(b)  Allowing receptacle to remain on street after certain hour. It shall be unlawful for any person to allow or permit, or cause to be allowed or permitted, any receptacle in which there has been deposited for collection, any refuse, to remain upon any of the streets, sidewalks or thoroughfares described and set forth in this subsection, after 10:00 a.m., whether or not such receptacle be then empty. 
(c)  Enumeration of streets to which this subsection applies. This subsection shall apply to the area bounded by the following streets or thoroughfares and shall apply to both sides thereof, bounding the area: 
    Roxboro Street, from Peabody Street to Holloway-Morgan Street Connector; 
    Holloway-Morgan Street Connector, from Roxboro Street to Mangum Street; 
    Morgan Street, from Mangum Street to Chapel Hill Street; 
    Peabody Street, from Chapel Hill Street to Roxboro Street. 
(Code 1964, §§ 9-42-9-44; Code 1982, §§ 10-67-10-69; Ord. No. 5496, § 2, 10-21-1980) 
Sec. 58-132. - Meddling with receptacles. 
    No unauthorized person shall meddle with or interfere with the contents of any receptacle set out for removal by the city. 
(Code 1964, § 9-29; Code 1982, § 10-70) 
Sec. 58-133. - Dead animals. 
(a)  Dead animals shall be removed from private property and disposed of by the city upon request for a fee to be set by the city council. Dead animals shall be removed from other property and disposed of by the city upon request at no charge. 
(b)  The term "dead animals" as used in this section shall mean the carcass of any small animal such as a dog, cat, squirrel, opossum, rabbit, rat, reptile, fowl, bird or any other of such size. Such term shall not be construed to apply to the carcass of a large animal such as a goat, sheep, pig, horse, mule, cow or the like. 
(Code 1964, §§ 9-1, 9-34; Code 1982, § 10-71; Ord. No. 7255, § 1, 6-29-1987) 
Sec. 58-134. - Disposal of target recyclables. 
    Target recyclables, as well as other recyclables handled by the city, are to be placed in a recycling bin and set out on the curb for collection. There shall be a fee, established by action of the city council, assessed to the property owner for mixing target recyclables with other refuse. 
(Code 1982, § 10-72; Ord. No. 11287, § 5, 11-3-1997) 
Secs. 58-135-58-151. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - REFUSE NOT COLLECTED BY THE CITY 

Sec. 58-152. - Hazardous refuse. 
    No hazardous refuse will be collected by the city, but such hazardous refuse shall be transported by the owner, responsible person or agent to the city disposal area and disposed of as prescribed and only to the extent allowed by the director pursuant to section 58-190. 
(Code 1964, § 9-36; Code 1982, § 10-76; Ord. No. 7000, § 9, 6-26-1986) 
Sec. 58-153. - Refuse from manufacturing, etc. 
    Refuse from manufacturing, wholesaling, assembly or processing operations will not be collected by the city. 
(Code 1964, § 9-37; Code 1982, § 10-77) 
Sec. 58-154. - Refuse from building operations, landscape work, etc. 
(a)  Generally. No building materials or refuse from building construction, demolition, repair or operations by contractors, or refuse from landscape work by landscape gardeners or other contractors shall be hauled by the city. 
(b)  Duty of building, etc., contractor. Building, plumbing, heating, masonry and similar contractors shall remove such refuse as may accumulate from their construction, repairing, remodeling or demolition of buildings. 
(c)  Duty of tree surgeons. Tree surgeons or others contracting to trim or remove trees shall haul their own refuse from the location at which they do work. 
(Code 1964, §§ 9-38-9-40; Code 1982, §§ 10-78-10-80) 
Sec. 58-155. - Stable manure. 
    Stable manure shall be removed by persons who maintain stables. 
(Code 1964, § 9-35; Code 1982, § 10-82) 
Sec. 58-156. - Tires. 
    No tires will be collected by the city, but such tires shall be transported by the owner, responsible person or agent to the city disposal area and disposed of as prescribed and only to the extent allowed by the director of sanitation or his or her designee. 
(Code 1982, § 10-83; Ord. No. 7841, § 4, 6-28-1989) 
Secs. 58-157-58-180. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - CITY DISPOSAL AREA 

Sec. 58-181. - Disposition of privately hauled refuse, etc. 
    The director may permit disposal of privately hauled refuse at a city disposal area under appropriate regulations and conditions. 
(Code 1964, § 9-45; Code 1982, § 10-90; Ord. No. 7000, § 3, 6-26-1986; Ord. No. 11287, § 6, 11-3-1997) 
Sec. 58-182. - Materials delivered to be city property. 
    All materials, properly delivered to a city disposal area, shall become property of the city. 
(Code 1964, § 9-46; Code 1982, § 10-91; Ord. No. 11287, § 6, 11-3-1997) 
Sec. 58-183. - Unauthorized separation, removal of materials delivered. 
    No person shall separate, collect, carry off, remove or dispose of materials delivered and deposited for disposal at the city disposal area unless authorized to do so by the director. 
(Code 1964, § 9-47; Code 1982, § 10-92; Ord. No. 11287, § 6, 11-3-1997) 
Sec. 58-184. - When disposal allowed. 
    Hours when disposal of refuse is permitted at the city disposal area shall be established by the director and posted on the premises, and no such disposal of any materials shall be made by any person at any time other than the hours so prescribed. 
(Code 1964, § 9-48; Code 1982, § 10-93; Ord. No. 7000, § 7, 6-26-1986; Ord. No. 11287, § 6, 11-3-1997) 
Sec. 58-185. - Responsibility of city for injuries to persons or vehicles. 
    The city will not be responsible for any injuries to persons hauling refuse to the city disposal area, while on the disposal area premises, nor will the city be liable for damage to vehicles from accidents on the premises. Provided, however, this section shall not be construed to apply to the employees of the city and city-owned equipment regularly employed on such premises. 
(Code 1964, § 9-50; Code 1982, § 10-95; Ord. No. 11287, § 6, 11-3-1997) 
Sec. 58-186. - Fees. 
    The city council may from time to time establish tipping fees for use of the city disposal areas. The city manager may provide for periodic billing to frequent users of the city disposal areas. 
(Code 1982, § 10-96; Ord. No. 7000, § 4, 6-26-1986; Ord. No. 11287, § 6, 11-3-1997) 
Sec. 58-187. - Target recyclables. 
    The tipping fees established by this division shall apply to target recyclables. Where the load is comprised in whole or in part of an amount of target recyclables, the tipping fee charged shall be an amount equal to two times the regular tipping fee. 
(Code 1982, § 10-96.1; Ord. No. 10588, § 1, 7-17-1995; Ord. No. 11287, § 6, 11-3-1997) 
Sec. 58-188. - Fees for violations. 
    The city council may from time to time establish fees to be assessed as civil penalties for violations of the ordinance from which this article is derived. 
(Code 1982, § 10-96.2; Ord. No. 11287, § 6, 11-3-1997) 
Sec. 58-189. - Use denied. 
    The director may deny any person or business entity use of the city disposal areas for failure to pay the fees prescribed herein, until those fees have been paid. 
(Code 1982, § 10-97; Ord. No. 7000, § 5, 6-26-1986; Ord. No. 11287, § 6, 11-3-1997; Ord. No. 13263, § 2, 6-5-2006) 
Sec. 58-190. - Disposal area regulations. 
    The city disposal areas shall be operated in accordance with the rules and policies established by the director and the laws of the state. The following items shall not be accepted at the city disposal areas: 
(1)  Waste determined by the director or the director's designee to be too hazardous to be safely disposed of at city disposal areas; and 
(2)  Automobiles and other items determined by the director to be inappropriate for a city disposal area. 
(Code 1982, § 10-99; Ord. No. 7000, § 8, 6-26-1986; Ord. No. 11287, § 6, 11-3-1997) 
Chapter 62 - STREETS AND SIDEWALKS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference- Authority of city generally, § 51 et seq. 
State Law reference- Powers of city regarding streets and sidewalks generally, G.S. 160A-296 et seq., 160A-306 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 62-1. - Building numbering. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of the owner of each house or other building to properly display on the front thereof, or on the grounds, in a position easily observed, the proper number of his or her house or other building. The owner shall make application to the city for such house or building number assignment. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for the owner of any house or other building to which a street number has been assigned and affixed to attach or paint, or permit to be or remain attached to, or painted on such house or other building, or on the grounds, any figure tending or purporting to indicate the street number on such house or other building or on the grounds, unless the number so indicated be the street number assigned to such house or other building as herein provided. 
(c)  Upon notice by the city to any owner or occupant of any house or other building, it shall be the duty of such owner or occupant, within ten days after such notice shall have been given, assigning to such house or other building a number, to cause such house or other building to be numbered as provided in subsection (a) of this section, at the expense of such owner or occupant. 
(d)  It shall be unlawful for any person to remove, obliterate or destroy any such number attached to, or painted on such house or other building, as required to be displayed by the provisions of subsection (b) of this section. 
(Code 1964, § 19-4; Code 1982, § 18-1) 
Sec. 62-2. - House number on face of curb. 
(a)  Required standard. It shall be unlawful for any person, group or business entity to paint house or building numbers on the face of the curb unless done in the following manner: 
(1)  Paint house or building number in luminous paint on a contrasting background; 
(2)  Locate the house or building number near the driveway cut for the house, building or lot, or in some other easily observed no-parking area upon which the structure or lot fronts; 
(3)  Use plain, unflourished block numbers that are at least four inches high where the face of the curb so permits such a minimum height, or the maximum height less than four inches that is possible on the curb face; and 
(4)  Paint only the proper house or building number as assigned pursuant to section 62-1. 
(b)  Additional requirements. Any person, group or business entity that proposes to paint house or building numbers on the face of the curb for hire shall first obtain a privilege license from the city collector of revenue. Any person or other entity shall obtain the permission of the owner or occupant of the house, building or lot prior to painting a number on the face of the curb upon which the structure or lot fronts. 
(Code 1982, § 18-1.1) 
Sec. 62-3. - Determination of street lines; furnishing engineering service. 
    The director of transportation and utilities shall have full power and authority to ascertain and determine the lines of any streets and shall furnish engineering service and advice to all departments of the city and to interested persons. 
(Code 1964, § 19-1; Code 1982, § 18-2) 
Sec. 62-4. - Duty of owner of property abutting improved sidewalks, etc., with reference to grading property or constructing retaining wall. 
    All owners of property abutting upon concrete, brick or other permanently improved sidewalks or curb and gutter shall grade such property or construct a retaining wall in such a manner as to prevent the washing of dirt, grass, trash or other material upon the sidewalks of the city. 
(Code 1964, § 19-5; Code 1982, § 18-3) 
Sec. 62-5. - Removal of material; permission required. 
    No person shall remove any sand, dirt or any other street building material from any street or sidewalk without permission of the city. 
(Code 1964, § 19-38; Code 1982, § 18-4) 
Sec. 62-6. - Spaces under sidewalks; cellar doors, grates, roofs-Generally. 
(a)  No person shall use or appropriate any space under a sidewalk for cellar or other underground uses without first obtaining a permit from the city council, which permit shall be revokable at the will of the council with or without notice. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to construct or maintain any cellar doors or grating on the sidewalks of the city without first obtaining a permit from the city council for the same. 
(c)  The sidewalk over any underground space shall be constructed and maintained by such permittee so as to permit travel over the same by pedestrians free from danger. The roofs over any such underground space or vault shall be of approved incombustible material. Glass, when used in the sidewalk over such underground space or vault shall be of approved incombustible material. Glass, when used in the sidewalk over such underground space or vault, shall measure not more than 16 inches square in one light, and each glass light shall be set in a metal shield and the joint filled with asphalt or some other acceptable material. The director of inspection services may revoke any permit granted for the building of any such roof or sidewalk whenever he or she shall ascertain that such roof or sidewalk is not being properly constructed or maintained. 
(d)  All such cellar doors or grates shall be on a level with the sidewalk and shall be kept in good repair by the owner or occupant of the abutting property. The design of cellar doors or grates shall conform to the requirements of the director of inspection services and the director of transportation and utilities. All such doors and grates shall be constructed of iron or some other indestructible material. 
(Code 1964, § 19-6; Code 1982, § 18-5) 
Sec. 62-7. - Same-Leaving open without providing guards and lights. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to leave open any cellar door or opening extending into the sidewalk, as provided for in section 62-6, without providing proper guards and lights to warn and protect the traveling public. 
(Code 1964, § 19-7; Code 1982, § 18-6) 
Sec. 62-8. - Duty of occupant of lot abutting street with reference to keeping sidewalk clear and gutter open. 
    The occupant of a lot abutting on any street shall keep the sidewalk clear and the gutter open and free from the obstructions as far as such lot extends. If any rubbish, dirt, ashes or other material be placed or left, without authority, on such sidewalk, or, in such gutter or street, the occupant of such lot shall remove the same within 12 hours after oral or written notice from the city. 
(Code 1964, § 19-8; Code 1982, § 18-7) 
Sec. 62-9. - Duty of owner of building with reference to drainage on or across sidewalks. 
    It shall be unlawful for the owner of any building or premises, to allow rainwater or drain water to drain from such building, lot or premises onto a sidewalk, or to allow gutters, ditches, leaders, ducts or drainpipes to empty onto the sidewalks. Such drainpipes or ducts shall be constructed to carry such water across the sidewalk areas to the gutter or a storm sewer, provided such drainpipes or ducts shall be constructed according to specifications prescribed by the city. Such drainage pipes, ducts and other devices for carrying such drain water or rain water across the sidewalk shall at all times be properly maintained in a safe manner by such property owner from whose property it runs. 
(Code 1964, § 19-9; Code 1982, § 18-8) 
Sec. 62-10. - Impeding flow of travel. 
(a)  It is unlawful to impede the regular flow of travel on a sidewalk in such a manner as to block a pedestrian's or motor vehicle's attempted passage into or out of a driveway, without leaving a safe and adequate alternative route into or out of the driveway. Consent to such blocking given by an owner, tenant, lawful occupant, or person in control of the property to which the driveway leads is an affirmative defense. 
(b)  It is unlawful to impede the regular flow of travel on a sidewalk in such a manner as to block a pedestrian's or motor vehicle's attempted passage into or out of an entrance or exit of any residence, business, or public facility, without leaving a safe and adequate alternative route into or out of the entrance or exit. Consent to such blocking given by an owner, tenant, lawful occupant, or person in control of the residence, business, or public facility is an affirmative defense. 
(c)  This section does not apply to acts to the extent they are allowed by, and done in conformity with, a permit issued by a governmental person. 
(d)  This section does not affect other sections of the City Code, including section 66-108 and 66-109. 
(Code 1964, § 19-14; Code 1982, § 18-9; Ord. No. 11490, § 1, 6-20-1998; Ord. No. 14845, § 3, 10-19-2015) 
Sec. 62-11. - Same-Dumping stumps, logs, etc., in street. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to dump, or cause to be dumped, any stumps, logs, bricks, concrete, metal or other like material, other than earth excavation approved by the city, in dedicated or accepted streets, sidewalks or other public ways. Any person violating this section shall be given a written notice by the city to move such materials within 15 days. 
(Code 1964, § 9-55; Code 1982, § 18-10) 
Sec. 62-12. - Maintenance of dangerous pit, embankment, etc., near or adjoining street or sidewalk. 
    It shall be unlawful for the owner, tenant or lessee of any premises adjacent to any street or sidewalk to maintain any dangerous pit, embankment, dangerous wall and like perilous thing near or adjoining any street or sidewalk. 
(Code 1964, § 19-18; Code 1982, § 18-11) 
Sec. 62-13. - Warning lights, etc.-Required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person engaged in building, altering or repairing the streets, sidewalks or other public ways of the city to leave such work in an unfinished condition without placing thereat sufficient lights or signs or other adequate means to warn the traveling public as approved by the director of transportation and utilities. 
(Code 1964, § 19-19; Code 1982, § 18-12) 
Sec. 62-14. - Same-Removing or damaging barricade or signs giving notice of dangerous conditions of street. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to remove, destroy, damage or tamper with any barricade, sign, lantern, torch or other device placed in any street, sidewalk or any other place by the city or anyone acting for the city or by any contractor, subcontractor or builder, intended to give notice to the traveling public that such street or portion thereof should not be traveled or as to the dangerous condition of the same or as to the existence of an obstruction. 
(Code 1964, § 19-20; Code 1982, § 18-13) 
Sec. 62-15. - Removing or damaging monuments designating street lines or elevations. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, engaged in the construction and repair of streets and sidewalks, to remove, relocate, destroy, damage or tamper with any monuments or metal pins designating street lines or elevations, unless approved by the director of transportation and utilities. 
(Code 1964, § 19-22; Code 1982, § 18-14) 
Sec. 62-16. - Depositing brine, acid, oil, etc., on streets or sidewalks. 
    No person shall empty or deposit on the streets, sidewalks or other public ways any saltwater, brine, acid, alkali, oil, paint or other hazardous substances that will damage the streets, sidewalks or other public ways or vehicles using the same or storm drainpipes into which the same may run. This section shall not prevent city staff or agents of the city from using before, during, or after a winter weather event any snow or ice removal technique (including, but not limited to, the use of saltwater or brine) that the public works department determines to be efficacious. 
(Code 1964, § 19-23; Code 1982, § 18-15; Ord. No. 14819, § 1, 8-3-2015) 
Sec. 62-17. - Closing and abandoning-Petitions, filing requirements. 
    Any person may file a petition requesting the city council to close any street or public alley or any part of a street or public alley. The petition shall be in writing and shall be filed with the city clerk. The petitioner or the petitioner's representative shall file with the petition the following: 
(1)  A map or sketch showing the street or public alley or part thereof which the petitioner requests to be closed; 
(2)  A description of the street or public alley or part thereof which the petitioner requests to be closed; 
(3)  An area map showing the surrounding streets and public alleys within two blocks in all directions of the street or public alley or part thereof which the petitioner requests to be closed; 
(4)  A statement of petitioner's reasons for requesting the closing; and 
(5)  If the petitioner proposes to construct any building, structure, or part thereof on any part of the area of the street or public alley or part thereof which petitioner requests to be closed, a site plan or sketch illustrating the construction and location of such construction. 
(Code 1964, § 19-75; Code 1982, § 18-16; Ord. No. 5510, § 1, 11-3-1980) 
Charter reference- Notice, § 51. 
State Law reference- Procedure for permanent closing of streets and alleys, G.S. 160A-299. 
Sec. 62-18. - Same-Compliance prerequisite to scheduling of hearing. 
    The city council shall not adopt a resolution setting a date for a public hearing, or authorizing and directing the city clerk to publish any notice of such public hearing, on any petition for the abandonment and closing of any public street, alley or other public way unless and until the provisions of section 62-17 have been complied with. 
(Code 1964, § 19-76; Code 1982, § 18-17) 
Sec. 62-19. - Withdrawal of street from dedication. 
    Any person who, pursuant to G.S. 136-96, withdraws from dedication land dedicated to public or private use as a street or roadway that is located in the city or in the city's extraterritorial area (if such exists), must furnish the documents indicated below to the city clerk, the city engineer, and the director of the city/county planning department at least 30 days before the declaration of withdrawal may be filed or recorded with the office of register of deeds: 
(1)  A cover letter indicating the name of the street or roadway and that the dedicated land is proposed to be withdrawn from dedication pursuant to G.S. 136-96 unless the city formally accepts the dedication within 30 days of receipt of the letter; 
(2)  The six-digit PID, or such other identifying numbers or information that the city manager determines to be sufficient, so that the location of the dedicated land proposed to be withdrawn can be clearly known, including a list of lots adjacent to the dedicated land proposed to be withdrawn; 
(3)  A copy of the declaration of withdrawal proposed to be recorded with the office of register of deeds and all related maps and plats proposed to be recorded; and 
(4)  If the proposed declaration lacks a description sufficient for identification of the dedicated land to be withdrawn, a legal description of the dedicated land to be withdrawn. 
(Code 1982, § 18-17.1; Ord. No. 7730, § 1, 3-20-1989) 
Sec. 62-20. - Encroachment of buildings, fences, etc. 
(a)  No person shall dig or lay the foundation of any house or other building within any street, sidewalk or other public way or erect any wall, fence or other structure abutting upon such street, sidewalk or other public way before ascertaining from the city the true property line and elevation of such street, sidewalk or other public way. 
(b)  The director of inspection services shall see that such foundation, building, house or other structure, except fences, retaining walls and steps when such steps are attached to and constitute a part of the building or structure in question, do not encroach upon the street, sidewalk or other public way in question. 
(c)  The director of inspection services shall see that such fences, retaining walls and steps, when steps are not attached to a building, and any other encroachments, do not encroach upon such street, sidewalk or other public right-of-way. 
(Code 1964, § 19-2; Code 1982, § 18-18) 
Sec. 62-21. - Tree limbs overhang, etc.-Prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to allow or suffer the limbs of trees, vines, bushes, shrubbery, flowers or other growth, or any trellis, fence, or other obstruction to project into or overhang a public sidewalk or other public way at a distance closer than seven feet above the surface of such sidewalk or other public way or in any manner so as to interfere with the free and safe passage of the public way or sidewalk by pedestrians or vehicular traffic. 
(Code 1964, § 19-24; Code 1982, § 18-19) 
Sec. 62-22. - Same-Constitutes nuisance. 
    The overhanging of a public sidewalk or other public way of branches or limbs or bushes, trees, shrubbery, vines, flowers, or other growth, or the overhanging or protruding into the public way of any trellis, fence, or other growth or construction, closer than seven feet above the surface of the sidewalk or other public way, or in any event, in such way as to interfere with the free and safe passage along the sidewalk or other public way by pedestrians and vehicular traffic, shall be and is hereby declared to constitute a public nuisance. Such public nuisance may be abated summarily by the city. 
(Code 1964, § 19-25; Code 1982, § 18-20) 
Sec. 62-23. - Same-Action by city. 
    If any owner, lessee or occupant of any property on which there is located any tree, bush, shrubbery, vine, fence, gate, trellis or other growth or construction with branches, limbs or parts overhanging a sidewalk or other public way in violation of the provisions of sections 62-21 and 62-22 shall fail, within the time specified and a notice from the authorized agency or department of the city to remove such parts of such growth or obstruction as are in violation of such sections, the city may, in addition to any other remedy, cut and remove all of such growth and obstruction as exists in violation thereof and such act on the part of the city shall be regarded as taken in the exercise of its governmental police power. 
(Code 1964, § 19-26; Code 1982, § 18-21) 
Secs. 62-24-62-49. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - CONSTRUCTION AND EXCAVATION IN THE PUBLIC WAY, INSTALLATION OF FACILITIES AND UTILITIES[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 14665, § 1, adopted August 18, 2014, amended the title of art. II to read as set out herein; and § 2, repealed div. 1, §§ 62-50-62-60 and enacted a new div. 1, §§ 62-50-62-57 to read as set out herein. Previously art. II was titled construction, excavation, etc.; and former div. 1 pertained to generally and was derived from Code 1964, §§ 19-27-19-31, 19-33-19-37; Code 1982, §§ 18-30-18-34, 18-36-18-41; Ord. No. 5147, § 1, adopted May 7, 1979; Ord. No. 11841, § 1, adopted October 18, 1999; Ord. No. 11841, § 1, adopted October 18, 1999 and Ord. No. 13094, adopted April 18, 2005. 

DIVISION 1. - WORK WITHIN PUBLIC WAY; UTILITIES; FRANCHISES, LICENSES, AND PERMITS 

Sec. 62-50. - Definitions. 
    The following words and terms in this division shall have the meaning given below unless the context indicates otherwise. These meanings shall apply whether a word is capitalized or not or is singular or plural. 
    Application, collocation, small wireless facility, utility pole, wireless facility, wireless infrastructure provider, wireless provider, wireless services, and wireless services provider are defined in Section 160A-400.51 of the North Carolina General Statutes or Federal Communications Commission Order FCC 18-133, whichever is more inclusive. 
    Authorization means permission from the city to do work in the public way or to maintain facilities in the public way and includes but is not limited to a franchise, a license, a permit, a letter, construction drawing approval. Multiple authorizations may be required for certain activities. 
    Contractor means and includes any of the following, licensed or unlicensed, performing work on an owner's behalf: contractor; subcontractor; or any employee or agent of a contractor, subcontractor, or owner. 
    Department means the department of public works of the city. 
    Emergency means a condition that poses a clear and immediate danger to life or health, or a significant loss of property, or requires immediate repair to restore service to a group of users of such service. 
    Emergency work means the replacement or repair of damage to active facilities, including main lines and services, where all 811 dig requirements are met. 
    Excavate means without limitation any cutting, digging, grading, tunneling, boring, or other alteration of the surface or subsurface material or earth in the public way. 
    Facilities means poles, pipes, culverts, conduits, ducts, cables, wires, fiber, amplifiers, pedestals, antennae, transmission or receiving equipment, other electronic equipment, electrical conductors, manholes, appliances, signs, poles, pavement structures, irrigation systems, landscaping, monument signs, monument mailboxes and any other similar equipment, for public or private use. 
    Owner means any property owner, company owner, or any entity by which work within the right-of-way has been ordered, or any entity on behalf of which any work within the right-of-way is caused to be performed, or any agent thereof. 
    Person means an individual, association, firm, partnership, limited liability company, joint venture, corporation, government, utility, or other organized entity able to contract for the activities described in this ordinance, whether for profit or not for profit. The term does not include the city. 
    Public way means the area that is used as, or offered, dedicated, or reserved for use as a public street, highway, alley, trail, sidewalk, curb, gutter, bike lane, bridge, round-about, tunnel, causeway, or shoulder, that is located in the city or in an area proposed for annexation to the city. The area also includes, without limitation, drainage areas and dedicated areas without surface improvements that are adjacent to improved areas, and areas where no roads or other improvements have been constructed but which are dedicated for one or more of the above uses. The public way encompasses the surface of the ground, and the area above and below the ground. 
    User means a person that proposes to place facilities in the public way, places such facilities, or owns or maintains such facilities. The term includes but is not limited to licensees and franchisees. 
(Ord. No. 14665, § 2, 8-18-2014; Ord. No. 15255, § 1, 2-5-2018; Ord. No. 15296, § 1, 5-21-2018; Ord. No. 15413, § 1, 12-17-2018) 
Sec. 62-51. - General conditions for use of the public way. 
    The provisions of this division apply to work performed in the public way and to facilities that have been placed in the public way. Noncompliance with a requirement in this division is a violation of the law and is subject to all remedies available under the law to the city. 
    The right to perform work in the public way and the ability to maintain facilities in the public way are allowed subject to the conditions below, as supplemented by those set forth in other sections of this ordinance, standards adopted by the department, and requirements contained in authorizations. 
(1)  The city does not warrant its legal interest in the public way. Persons doing work in the public way and users may need to obtain approvals from persons with property interests in the public way. 
(3)  An authorization does not grant exclusive rights to provide a service or to a particular location unless such rights are explicitly guaranteed in an authorization. 
(4)  The city retains all rights it may have to use all portions of the public way for any purpose not prohibited by law. 
(5)  An authorization does not convey any legal right, title, or interest in the public way. 
(6)  The city and its officials, officers, and employees are not liable for any direct, indirect, or consequential damages that result when facilities in the public way are damaged during the construction, installation, inspection, maintenance, or repair of public improvements that have received city funding or that are installed pursuant to a contract with the city. 
(7)  Users and persons who cause work to be done in the public way shall pay for all damage that results, directly or indirectly, from work performed for their benefit in the public way, and for the installation, repair, maintenance, and operation of their facilities in the public way. 
(8)  Nonenforcement of one or more provisions of an authorization does not waive the city's right to enforce the provisions of an authorization. 
(9)  An authorization creates no third party rights against the city and is intended only for the benefit of the person receiving the authorization. 
(10)  An authorization does not limit the city's exercise of its regulatory, police, governmental, legislative, or contracting authority. A subsequent ordinance may regulate users more strictly than is provided in prior authorizations received by such users. If an authorization conflicts with the terms of another authorization or with the city code, the stricter of the applicable provisions shall control. The stricter provision shall not control, however, if a later-issued authorization or ordinance explicitly and specifically states that particular terms are to override prior, less strict terms in an authorization. 
(Ord. No. 14665, § 2, 8-18-2014) 
Sec. 62-52. - Work in public way requiring prior notice; authorizations; standards; fees. 
(a)  Work requiring prior notice to department. Persons and users shall give prior notice to the department of the following activities, and obtain necessary authorizations before initiating the work: 
(1)  Excavation or restoration within the public way, including but not limited to construction of new portions of the public way; 
(2)  Cutting, moving, or alteration of any pipe, conduit, pole, meter, fire hydrant, facility, or other equipment or structure owned by the city, or attachment to such objects; 
(3)  Installation or repair of facilities within the public way including but not limited to placing facilities on other facilities already located in the public way; 
(4)  Construction of private streets (including but not limited to paving and gutters), sidewalks, or alleys; 
(5)  Installation or repair of facilities for the conveyance of water, sewer, or stormwater; and 
(6)  Installation or repair of facilities for electrical, gas, video, internet, telephone, cable, telecommunications, television, or other information or data transfer service to customers within the city. 
(b)  Authorizations - franchises, licenses, permits, construction drawings, and other approvals. The department may require, in its discretion, one or more authorizations for the work described in (a), and may require submission of all information it deems necessary for receipt of such authorization(s). The department shall determine, in its discretion whether a franchise, a license, a permit, construction drawings, or other type of authorization shall be required, or multiple authorizations, for work described in (a) and for users with facilities in the public way. 
(c)  Unlawful to do work without authorizations; emergency. Except in the event of an emergency, it shall be unlawful to do work in the public way or maintain facilities in the public way without authorizations that may be necessary. In the event of an emergency, a person may do such work as is necessary to address the emergency. Application shall immediately be made for necessary authorizations from the city, notwithstanding that work may have started or have been completed and all necessary fees shall be paid. 
(d)  Standards. The department shall develop standards and requirements for authorizations, including but not limited to franchises, licenses, permits, and other approvals, and may attach conditions to such authorizations. The department may also develop standards and requirements for doing work in the public way when an authorization is not required. 
(d)  List of contractors. The department may require that franchisees and persons who contract to have work performed in the public way maintain an updated list of the contractors working on their projects, and acknowledge responsibility for the actions of the contractors on the public way. 
(e)  Fees; accounts.
